comments.comment_body: The Oscars are meaningless to me. Scorsese got snubbed for best director when he was doing his best work. I don’t know who makes those decisions and I really don’t care.
If only Ricky Gervais were hosting.

For the most part I enjoy watching the Oscars but what I really enjoy is the TCM network airing "31 Days Of Oscars" which showcases movies that have won or have been nominated for Oscars over the decades.  In the past couple days I have seen "From Here To Eternity," "Annie Hall" and "Interiors."  TCM is my favorite movie channel.

The Academy is overwhelmingly male and white. As are the decision makers and power players.  

I sense a tremor that will become an earthquake in the next two decades, when the small numbers of minorities, including women, continue to tip the balance. 

Until then, as audiences we can continue to seek out films based on their merits, and not on their marketing budgets. One quibble I have is the call-out that somehow JLo was robbed of a nomination (see Carlos Aguilar's Jan. 13 op-ed in this paper). 

Jennifer Lopez is not a strong, actress, in any film she's been in.  She has a strong, charismatic presence. And her success, she owns it, she deserves it. But an Oscar performance, nah.

With respect, may I suggest that whether readers pay attention to the Spirit awards, the Oscars, or some other awards is neither here nor there?

Our society has become obsessed with keeping score and rating things. The publiciity, glitz, and competition surrounding thse awards and scores detract from our enjoying quality culture for its own sake. 

There's no way to prove it, but the suspicion persists that all the attention paid to awards makes for mediocre movies, and discourages true genius, originality, merit. 

If we turn out backs on awards, the world will be a better place. (Same with social media, by the way.)

When my husband and I go to a movie we choose based on favorite actors, favorite directors, word-of-mouth of friends, reviews by reviewers we respect.  I don’t think, “I want to see a movie about race relations; where can I find one of those.”  

I thought “Green Book” was just terrific.  The performances of the two lead actors were so nuanced and real.  And, my father, a real WASP if there ever was one, had several Don Shirley albums back in the day.  I remember him playing them regularly.  That fact added particular enjoyment of the film for me.

The Oscars are a tradition.  Some years, I agree with the selections, some years I think a movie or performer should have been nominated.  They can’t nominate all the good movies or all the great performances; that’s an impossible task.  Viewers watch to see their favorite stars, dish about what they’re wearing, rate the acceptance speeches.  Maybe it is silliness but I have always enjoyed the once-a-year spectacle.  

Today we went to see the nominated live-action short subjects so that we’d be Oscar-ready.  Tomorrow, we’ll watch the show and my sister and I will telephone back and forth, “Was that outfit terrible or WHAT?”  Then, in a few weeks, I will have forgotten who won.

Does anyone really watch these things?  A bunch of wealthy, oddly dressed, chemically and surgically preserved celebrities patting themselves and occasionally each other on the back? I love film (Uncut Gems is great!), but why do we need to supplement Hollywood's grossly inflated salaries and egos with multiple awards shows?  Why not a huge celebration for best teacher, best caregiver, best nurse, etc.?  It's ridiculous when you think about it.

Well, pretty soon all the complaining about there’s not enough this, there’s not enough that - no one will even go to movies at all.

I bet anything theaters have noted a decrease in sales.  There are probably a good number of reasons.  

I don’t care what color the actors are, what religion, what gender, any of that - just give us a good story with decent actors and we’ll show up.  

Popcorn, please.

There’s also this festival in France called the Cannes Film Festival. Widely regarded as the most important and prestigious of all festivals and awards, somehow Cannes’ carefully curated jury of actual cinephiles and auteurs are able to get right what 7000 Oscar members never seem able to.
Tired of being asked to watch industry award shows.  Does anybody watch the annual tax preparer award show?  The sanitation engineer of the year? Letter carrier?

So if you disagree with it, ignore it?

Furthermore, who cares?  And why do we need the same articles written every year?  Can't we save people some time by just republishing the same ones from years past.  They are going to say the same thing.

It's art - it's supposed to be objective.  Just because you don't like it doesn't mean it's bad anymore than your liking it means it's good.  

It's really not that hard.

Actually, we shouldn’t be caring about either of them or any other awards show. They’re meaningless, trite awards for...entertainment??? They need validation from themselves, for themselves. Just a waste of time and energy all the way around.

Come on, how many editorials have been in the Times these past few weeks about the lack of diversity in the Oscars. I get it, really I do but these endless editorials are just numbing and sometimes people who get nominees are really the ones that deserve them. Just nominating someone to show diversity is just ridiculous.

Please NYTs ease off these constant “wokeness” pieces.

Thank you for offering an alternative rather than more complaining. The Oscars are not going to change anytime soon - the academy is dominated by a bunch of old white people. Their tastes are pedestrian and boring and just plain conventional. Why do seemingly woke stars even indulge them? More stars should follow Woody Allen’s example and simply not go. Hollywood does not make the best movies in the world and hasn’t in some time. The only people claiming it does are American English speakers who can’t or won’t watch foreign films or simply unable to say this because their careers are so tied up in the “film industry” (I.e. the majority of entertainment journalists and various other hangers on).
I go to movies to enjoy myself not spend hours worrying about the color of someone's skin. This is racist.
Award shows can be a dagger in the heart of creativity. I wish there was some other way to promote creativity.
I saw Pulp Fiction. Where's my award?

This appears to be about a group of people trying to convince the public that they should support certain movies because of the gender or ethnicity of the actors and that they have relatively modest financial support. All this as more important than the actual story or quality of the film. No thanks. You can keep your backwards woke unsensibilities out of my entertainment.
All award shows are worthless.
#Oscarsareawasteoftime.

Agreed on all points here, except that Forbes list of $10m spent by A list actresses to get ready for the Oscars is a joke. Literally all of it is either comped or borrowed. I remember at an Oscars party at Chateau Marmont one year an actress telling half the room, including me, that she was APPALLED that a woman in the gift bag area (there are many dozens of these swag hand-out events during Oscar week) was selling her jewelry FOR MONEY. This actress made a federal case out of it, saying everything should always be free for actresses, as it usually is. She wanted a necklace the woman had made that was gold and diamonds and she felt completely insulted that she should have to pay for it. Welcome to Hollywood. So yes, get the truth out that it's just a bunch of spoiled narcissistic and intellectually vacant robots. It really is.

Wow, the Oscars not being sufficiently woke, when they are far to the left of the American mainstream, tells you everything you need to know about the modern New York Times. 

Some of us still believe in the founding notion of meritocracy, not quota-based thinking. It’s SO obvious. Remember the #oscarsowhite “scandal?” What a scandal that in a majority white country they tend to make movies about the majority population. And if the left were sincere, they’d take issue with the dramatic overrepresentation of Jews in the industry. But that would be “racist,” for some reason, though applying the exact same logic as the social justice left when it comes to “whites.” 

We are growing tired of the endless double standards.
Identity politics driven racial quota Oscars for the Woke! Where do I sign up?

Every year there is a batch of NYT opinion writers beating up the Oscars for being too white. This is tasteless and racist, I say may the best movie win. I don't see the same columnists ever complaining that the NBAs are too black. Why so? 

Maybe each race should have their own Oscars, to save the drama. As a white woman, I prefer to watch and award movies with people who look like me and I understand the need of minorities to watch and award movies with people who look like them.

I just don't like to be forced to watch, like, and award movies I don't like by the thought police squad, of which columnists like this one, is a member.

The Oscars, originally a mostly in-house directed Rotary Club style bun fest of understandable narcissistic self-congratulation was soon reconfigured by sharp-eyed media hucksters as a form of marketing the Hollywood system and its movies. And for decades it served as a purely commercial and highly successful promotional exercise that gave the public what they wanted - famous beautiful people, red carpets, "daring gowns" and all. Because of the Oscars success in harvesting eyeballs and attracting attention coupled with the largely ludicrous assumption that the awards were also a reflection of some sort of merit (something like the admissions process to the Ivy League) and not an exercise in intra-industry log rolling and money (see Miramax), the social engineering crowd, always keen to beat an always intolerably recalcitrant lumpen over their insufficiently "woke" heads with their preferred narratives laid siege to the callow and shallow, show us which of the moment social justice cause parade we need to get in the lead of - as long as it does not cost us -dream factories of Los Angeles with predictable results - nose diving ratings resulting from the flight of an uncooperative lumpen to online porn and TMZ.

Entertainment awards are out of control.  Rich people patting each other on the behind, archaic rules and decision making, ego stroking and PR hyperbole.  Really boring stuff, like so many of the movies these days that win 'awards'.  Tone it down, Academy, you're just not that special.

Yes the Oscars are very mainstream and very safe.  Always have been, always will be.    But I'm still going to watch them because they are an institution.   I don't rely on the Oscars to tell me what's good but I do get excited when great films from Pedro Almodóvar and Bong Joon-ho get recognition as they have this year.

I pay attention to the Independent Spirit Awards as well.  But  I would not be so eager to claim the ISA's so "woke."   Once you start pulling things apart to find them  "problematic" it never stops.  I'm sure there are many many ISA winners the PC police would find very objectionable.  And frankly I'd say those films are all the better for it.  Art made in the service of ideology is not art.  It's propaganda.
Plenty of awards. Try not telling people what they ought to do based upon your own world view.

Another sensational, non news, confusing opinionated piece in the NYTimes. Following the Fox News path of commenting on the news rather than digging to find good stories, ugh. The financial times and yes even the WSJ are doing a much better job. But look, I’m not sorry that there are other people who don’t have your taste but so it goes. This is a sensational headline followed by a critic claiming racial bias when perhaps it’s just a different set of artistic values.  Then again I could be wrong: its a conspiracy of white people trying to suppress new  talent and predictably its people of color or women? Critics love to define and then dictate what’s good or bad but in the end you should make up your own mind. Long live the academy AND the independent spirit awards.

All contests and competitive awards in the arts are bogus.  They may serve to draw an audience to a gallery or a cinemax screening, but there is no possible way to say "Little Women" is better than "Parasite" which is better than "Once Upon a Time. . . and on and on. Anyone paying attention knows this. We just like to play games, and these games stand in for true analysis and enjoyment.  They serve only these interests $$$$$$$$$$$$$.

I stopped caring about The Oscars a LONG time ago. I think it was exactly the moment when Julia Roberts won. But I digress. Hey folks, it's a private club that none of us are in. They happen to televise it. If there was some sort of democracy or public input to it, then they'd call it something like, oh, I don't know, The People's Choice Awards. LOL. Anywho... you can care about the rich pretty folks all pretending to be grateful to the PR machine that put them up on the stage or you can do something more meaningful with your time like hang out with your kids at the park or walk your dog.
I was hoping this would be an argument against award shows generally.  Unfortunately, Ms. Walsingham is just shilling for yet another awards show.  Oh well.
Never heard of the Spirits Award

I liked Driving Miss Daisy.  I liked If Beale Street Could Talk.  I liked Green Book.   None of these even come close to a few of the favorites I never tire of:

Casablanca
To Kill A Mockingbird
The Natural
The Help
Auntie Mame
Psycho
Schindler's List
The Philadelphia Story
The Shawshank Redemption
Thelma and Louise
To Catch A Thief
Out of Africa
The Deer Hunter
The Bad Seed
Fried Green Tomatoes
The Road To Perdition
Singing In The Rain
Top Hat
Serpico
Might have agreed with you until I read that Uncut Gems took major awards tonight. It's a movie for our ADD times, perhaps, but it's undramatic and incoherent. Direction, Editing, Best Actor. Oh my.

I faithfully boycott all movie awards telecasts. While I enjoy good movies and am amazed at great acting, the events are so smarmy and self-congratulatory that I want to puke. I have allowed, however, that when TV presents a spectacular covering the Nobel Prize Awards, I will start watching the Oscars and Spirit and Golden Globes. I'm not holding my breath.

Since all anybody seems to care about is the racial/gender representation of the nominees and winners of the Oscars and Grammys let’s just end the madness. Cancel these shows and either give everyone a trophy or make segregated awards where everyone involved “looks like you.”
I couldn't care less about who wins the Oscars, but please show the dresses on the red carpet.
How about this for an idea? Just watch movies  you like, and form your own opinions about which ones are especially good.
As the kids say, First World problems.

Hey Veronica, 

Who made you the “big maven” of culture and art? It’s really in the eye of the beholder, and for many years, the Spirit Awards has also awarded films subjectively. Many of you 
“know it all” artistic types have a tendency to select films, plays, music, and art that pertain to just your own cultural heritage and history.  You really only see a film as being a work of art if it shows the particular suffering of people just like you.
So basically "Their awards are bad, our awards are good."  Got it.
Uncut Gems was frenetic, bleak, and ultimately plain unbearable.  Who cares how skillfully done it was when it was not worth doing?
Or you could just not watch either like the majority of people.
Have to say that "If Beale Street Could Talk" was not much better than "Green Book" . How about just not paying attention awards shows at all? There are too many.

At some point in his entire process the pundits o' plenty [POP] have forgotten that works of art do not get their place in the world or indeed the pantheon via a cheesy TV show of any description.

Dazed and Confused exists and delights not due to any snubs by the major or minor award shows.... just as the dude abides.

And like the dude - I will watch neither.
I don;t pay attention any more; it's not worth the minutes out of my life.

The uber-woke crowd is nothing if not predictable. Without looking at the byline, I would have guessed Farhad Manjoo wrote this. 

No need to worry if you wish to see the Oscars get ignored. Social media companies are succeeding at turning most young humans into a bunch of catatonic, vegetative, device addicted zombies. The typical young adult now has such a short attention span that s/he can't sit down and watch a relatively short 90 minute movie, let alone a 3-hour awards ceremony. 

By the end of the 2020s, I predict that the Oscars will no longer be broadcast on network television, having been banished away like the baseball playoffs minus the World Series in favor of some "reality" TV programming.

How about, Both. There are great films nominated on th Oscars and it’s a fun evening. You can complain about everything with the hunger the internet has for searching out a issue to get page hits. I’ll ignore the negativity and do what’s fun.
I just streamed The Petrified Forest. You know, with Bette Davis, Leslie Howard and Humphrey Bogart.

Enough with all these complaints. Broadcast Best Black awards on one evening. Best Latin awards the next. Follow that up on a third consecutive evening with Best Asian awards. And finally, on night #4, Best Caucasian Awards. It will be like first grade. There will be no losers. 

And no viewers either.
I pretty much avoid all these self congratulatory backslapping events that promote the people so thy can cash in more next year.
Yet another first world problem. With all of challenges in today's' world, who care about awards given to actors?

So let's see if I understand: the only movies that truly deserve acclaim are radical, leftist, edgy screeds sympathetically portraying some minority or female characters in a never-ending struggle against the while male heteronormative Christian oppressors. 

Hopefully, there are a few people out here who can understand that it is not possible for me to take such nonsense seriously.

I have a better idea: how about we have an awards ceremony where we screen out nominees that feature immoral content and means of production? No nominees with vulgar language. No nominees that involved the commission of sin in the making of the movie. No nominees that feature sinful behavior that could serve as a strong inducement for viewers to commit such sins.

If any change is called for, it's time to demand more virtue from our movies, as opposed to continuing to try to divy up humanity into a ridiculous taxonomy of racial, ethnic, sexual, and deviant categories, with an overlay of mindless leftist political activist filters, in order to keep some infantile chalkboard tally going.
nomination by committee = democracy?

The Oscars already have separate awards for actors and actresses, so the obvious solution to the problems raised in this article is to have separate awards for best white and black actor/actress, best white and black male director and female director, best latin actor/actress, best asian actor/actress, best lgbtq actor/actress, etc. 

It only makes sense.

What used to be a fun tradition, to watch the academy and other awards shows each year ended for me when Brokeback Mountain was snubbed for best picture. The Grammys are the same. I gave up on that hellish show long ago when new 'music' categories were created for what I as a musician refer to as noise, not music. I haven't watched an awards show since and rarely if ever will I go and pay $12-$18 to sit in a theatre where I have to pre-pick my seat, as if risking my life on a sub-par airline flight. 
It seems the 'awards' industry is just that; an industry whose goal is just like our economy, to make money not art or entertainment. If the academy spent as much time picking great movies as the actresses and actors spend picking their outfits (or lack of clothing) and walking the red carpet, maybe it would be worth watching. But I doubt it. It's as political as politics and that's enough reason to stay away.

i was all set to believe you. But then you mentioned Pulp Fiction. Apparently I’m in the minority, but the appeal of that movie truly mystifies me.

Of course, I loved Motherless Brooklyn and Jo Jo Rabbit, both of which received some pretty scathing reviews. Nevertheless, I sat in the movie theater immersed in their worlds, and I was sorry when they were over.

I haven’t gone to a movie in 3 years

I used to go often for decades

I dislike the people who go to movies...

The first movie in theatre I ever saw was Dr Zhivago age 16. My friend fell asleep. I watch it once a year. and many others

Thereafter sat alone in front row center. I become immersed and weep at every movie...almost

Soon I will get a bigger TV so I can weep alone with better popcorn 

In safety 

You can never go home?

I never leave

One thought regarding Driving Miss Daisy: Yes, race is certainly one of the themes in the film, but not by far the only one. The film and the play before it were about the Jewish community in a certain place and time; it is about fitting in while retaining one’s identity; it is about anti-Semitism and the Temple bombing, and a community trying to maintain its traditions while under a multitude of threats from the outside. And yes, it is about the relationship between two peoples each with its own story of oppression. In other words it should not be viewed through the single lens of race alone; it’s not always just about that. Other people have stories as well that are worth telling.

I love many movies and usually watch the Oscars, but not this year and maybe never again. I recently saw JUST MERCY and was amazed with Jamie Foxx's performance. If this had been a story about a white man, and if that actor portrayed the role as incredibly beautifully as Mr. Foxx did, he would have been nominated, and he would have won. I was also angry about the snubbing of BlackKklansman last year. It was an important film that was well-directed and well-acted. It helped me (a white women) increase my understanding of life for black people....and why black people fear many police. (And I see that in real life too.)

I am also tired of Hollywood's omission and narrow view of women. LITTLE WOMEN was beautifully directed by Greta Gerwig, and it ended with a powerful statement by Jo March. I would enjoy seeing many more movies about the lives of women, both historical and modern. But I'm tired of categories women are slotted into....the fem fetal, the aggressively sexy ones, the ditzy ladies, the old women who are there only to serve the men in their lives. I want more smart interesting women in all kinds of roles.Women from all class and racial backgrounds. A lot fewer power women like WONDER WOMAN and a lot more power women like we saw in HIDDEN FIGURES.

I will continue to see movies in the theater and at home, and I will appreciate the fine films and the people who make them. If any of them are honored with an Oscar I may read it in th next mornings paper.....or not.

The Oscars, in my observation, favors Hollywood formula, technically proficient films. On the other hand, the notion that Pulp Fiction, which was exactly what its title stated it was, should have won anything, is a popular delusion I don't understand.

I am reading this while spending some time in a developing country - working on topics of overconsumption + climate crisis.

From my perspective here, the awards and associated cost (> I read your Forbes reference) are just unbelievable excess and a slap in the face to anyone who cares about this planet. - A cruise to Antactica for all nominees - really? You mean, a photo op while we still have it? Obliviousness, with well rehearsed philanthropy sprinkled in. 

I do not care who gets nominated and who doesn't because the event is wrong on a systemic level. I love good cinema, even the occasional guilty pleasure Hollywood drama - - but it does not need to be such an extravaganza.
Fiddling while Rome (Earth) is burning.

There is no evidence all of the Spirit Awards voters have watched all of the movies, either. 
And it has its own inherent bias -- the voters are all people who have decided to join the organization. Certainly, this draws a certain type of person, whatever that may be. And I'm sure there's plenty of politics involved, ust as there is at the Oscars.

I just saw this movie, so, after reading this opinion piece, what instantly sprung to my mind was Little Women directed by Greta Gerwig. Every generation has had its own film adaptation of Little Women. I would love nothing more than to thank Greta Gerwig personally for giving me and so many women and girls of my generation ours and for her love and care that went into crafting this profoundly inspiring take on a novel that is a fixture in my life and in those of many women and girls, both in America and around the world (Little Women, the novel by Louisa May Alcott, on which Gerwig's film is based, has been translated into more than 50 languages).  

Gerwig, regrettably, was not nominated for Best Director for her masterful rendition of Little Women in an era that has seen enormous strides for women in American culture writ large. I am frustrated and disappointed that rather than acknowledging those cultural shifts by honoring the director of such a tour de force, the Academy saw fit to deprive Gerwig of a rightly-deserved Oscar nomination for Best Director, and, in doing so, refused to acknowledge the impact and necessity of placing woman-centered narratives on as high a pedestal as male-centric ones.

I don't like art of any sort being graded and listed in order of anyone's votes, and every award group that didn't recognize "Sorry to Bother You" in 2018 disappointed me. Beale Street made me want to go back and read the book, and was better than most of the 2019 Oscar nominees, but I thought it was a good movie in a bad year. That's all. I thought it was also flawed. Its themes feeling relevant a half century later made for good thought and conversation, and all due respect to the critics who reflect my opinions less as I get old than they did when I was young. But I wasn't upset and disappointed; I've never expected much from awards shows and have usually got what I expected.

It's all subjective.  I loved the movie Forest Gump.  I have no desire to see something called "Crash".  People enjoy different things.  The Oscars is more of a popularity contest.  In the scheme of things frankly it's not a big deal.  I won't watch it, and frankly rarely go to see a movie anymore.  Many are depressing and violent.  I'm depressed enough reading the news.  I don't need to pay to get even more depressed.  Feel free to celebrate the types of films you would like to.  But don't criticize what other people like.
Why go to movies, loud and pricey, when you have a surfeit of offerings within easy reach of the remote?

First of all the very concept of the best anything is ludicrous. There could be the worst picture, or performance award.  And that would be  entertaining. Some movies and actors are so bad they're laughable. But the overwhelming majority of them do what they are paid to do and do it well. Is there the best plumber of the year award? What about the best performance by a physician award?  I hope not.  The idea that there is a best performance award I think is an insult to the acting craft. Especially since most of the winners ride on an intense emotional outburst. As if the pondered response to  the possibility that her husband is cheating on her disqualifies it as inferior acting. I've been  impressed by actors at Juilliard and actors in outdoor Shakespeare theater companies as much as by actors on the silver screen. Do they have to win academy awards? OK. Let's say it's entertaining and fun, sort of like a game of cards and leave it go at that. Posterity decides on the best movies and the best performances, because they enthrall audiences 50 year from now as today. To riff on the great Bob Dylan (who incidentally won an award himself): We don't need Oscar to tell us which way an actor's going.
Which one will Ricky Gervais be hosting? That's one I'll watch.

I did more than forget the Oscars.  I've more or less forgotten the American 'entertainment industry', another wing of the post-modern chamber-of-commerce-ism that would have us believe that the route to contentment and fulfillment lies along the path of consumption and shallow diversion.   That, as perfectly exemplified by the current occupant of the White House, is the true 'sham'.

I trust friends' and family's movie recommendations as to movies.  I've seen too many Academy Award winners/nominees that made me roll my eyes.

While it's doubtless that the Academy has different criteria than I do, I no longer use them to help choose my movies (aside from "I think I'll give that a miss"), and gave up watching the Oscars decades ago.

The "Politically Correct but Unrealistic Awards", ie. Spirit Awards are not preferable over the Oscars.  However I totally agree with forgetting the Oscars.  It's just a bunch of movie industry people unduly influenced by political correctness giving themselves awards.  How is that entertaining or fulfilling?

For better or worse, the Oscars have been the leading awards show for past 92, and are thus of incredible culture importance. The films chosen and discussion around them show a microcosm of society at that specific point in time. There are plenty of awards shows but there is no replacement for the Oscars. -NW
Industry awards show are off my list entirely, irrespective of the industry.

IMHO the Oscars have been forgettable for the last few decades.  For example, I would never torture myself with La La Land.  I think this is a good idea.  I think this is the way to democratize Hollywood.

Well, of course the Oscars are pure scandal and entertainment and hardly worth watching if you don't enjoy that sort of thing. But the same goes for all the other narcissistic and self-flattering awards ceremonies, including the Spirit prizes. 

And by the way if the author really believes that the shallow and obvious "If Beale Street Could Talk" was in any way an award-worthy, or even adequate adaptation of James Baldwin's fine novel, I would like to kindly disagree.

Last year I watched the Oscars because my wife, who rarely does, wanted to (she loved Rami Malek in "Bohemian Rhapsody", with good reason, too. She also loved "A Star is Born").   I would have remembered why I don't watch the Oscars, except I hadn't forgotten.  
It was worse than I remembered!

Films and performances are myriad that are timeless, but passed over by the misnamed "Academy" (an academy is a place of study).   The history of the Awards could best be studied by everything from Citizen Kane, to Raging Bull, and many more before and after both.

So, no, again this year, I will NOT be watching.  Hopefully the Spirit Awards will be more representative, as the NY Film Critics' Awards usually are, too.

I don't understand this persistent campaign to bring awards to the forefront of the cultural conversation, as if they have any meaning in real life except to the rich and famous of Hollywood. Awards are not that important the us average folks. It's just a TV show. 

If you want to talk about what messages are being put forth in movies themselves, that's a valid conversation, but awards have little to no value in our culture. Please stop treating awards shows as a soapbox for airing complaints about "snubs" based on sex and race. 

Who's to say who is deserving and who isn't, which is precisely why awards don't matter any more than critic's year-end best of lists. Maybe it's a fun diversion, but there's really no there there.

If you want to make awards even less relevant, if that's even possible, keep making demands of "inclusion" that hopelessly muddy the waters about whether someone is being given an award just because of a need to meet a diversity quota. We're already one step closer to giving everyone a participation trophy so that no one gets their feelings hurt.

Rich people's problems.

We see your eschewing of the Oscars and raise you everything that passes for"culture" in the arts, mass media, print media and popular music.  Except classical music, the only indispensable, non-disposable expression in this or any other reality you imagine.

I don't own a t.v. or a smartphone. Couldn't watch any awards show if I even cared. 

For your consideration.
If your not a movie star,director,  part of the PR machine then just enjoy the movies and move on.  to many other real  issues to really think about.

The purpose of all awards is to amplify inequality. There are many fine movies. What is the point of selecting a single one of them for exaltation? The answer is that we crave inequality; we need something to idolize.

Ignore all the awards, experience the movies fully and write about the ones that really move you.
Thanks for the reminder, just flipped it on, with pen and paper, making my must-see list. So many interesting films — yes, this year’s Oscar award list came up short for me too.

Oh, boy.  The Spirit Awards, which purport to honor "independent" film, routinely give their prizes to big stars and multi-million dollar productions no actual "independent" filmmaker could dream of.

And, because the organization is run by arts administrators, the diversity thing is marketed along with the unearned reputation for supporting non-commercial moviemaking.

This is some crusade ... who knew the Oscars were the pinnacle of injustice in American society.

Green Book, despite being vilified by the Woke crowd, is actually a wonderfully written, acted and directed movie.

Is the deep down conviction that the Republic can survive Donald Trump optimism or denial? I think it's the latter. At least since 9/11, but actually since the Vietnam War, the United States has been losing legitimacy and the operative consensus needed for its vast bureaucracy to function. Three impeachments, two electoral college victories that went to the candidate with fewer votes, a series of lost wars, an economy as unbalanced as at any time in history, all point to the breakdown of the political order. The shock we felt in 2016 was our instinctive recognition that this dysfunctional election signaled the end of American democracy. We need to hold on to the truth of that shock, even as its impression fades. The fantasy that an election in 2020 can make things right is the most dangerous distraction that those of us who oppose Trump face. No, the Republic has not survived Trump, and it's time for people of good faith to start trying to imagine what comes next, and to mitigate the damage that the coming collapses threaten. Elections can no longer save us.

This column fills me with a sense of nostalgia and gloom -- Eugene McCarthy's 1968 Presidential Campaign By 1967, opposition to the war in Viet Nam was spreading throughout the Democratic Party. Many were frustrated at their inability to curtail the war even though the Democrats controlled the federal government. Dissident Democrats began looking for someone to challenge the re-election of President Lyndon B. Johnson in the Spring primaries. Many considered it, but the only high ranking Democrat willing to step forward was Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota. [...] In 1968, winning the primaries did not necessarily win delegate votes at the national convention. The delegate selection process was often quite separate from the popular vote, and usually controlled by the state party. Consequently, McCarthy only received 23 percent of the 2622 votes at the convention in August. Vice President Hubert Humphrey, a former Senator from Minnesota who replaced LBJ as the candidate of the party establishment, got the nomination on the first ballot with 67 percent. Torn by dissent, the Democrats lost the Presidency in November by a razor thin margin. This election prompted the Democrats to reform the nomination process...and required that African-Americans, women and youth be better represented at the convention. The nature of the nominating process was never the same again. https://www.jofreeman.com/photos/McCarthy.html

It has been said often: Trump is an existential threat to the republic and our democracy. That is not a trite statement, he is a frighteningly real threat that has become more frightening, more real as Republican depravity has been exposed through the impeachment and trial of Trump. Yet there exists another existential threat to America...true believers. True believers are dangerous for their blind uncompromising loyalty. They are devoted by feelings and belief to a person or a cause - for them, there exists no alternative. From the far right to the center right, blind uncompromising loyalty to Trump has brought us to the precipice of republican (both little "r" and big "R") suicide. There has been such a short, steep slope to the full exposure of Republican depravity that "precipice of peril" describes our times. On the far left, Bernie's Bro's constitute true believers just as dangerous as Trump's MAGAts. For them the November election is Bernie's way or the highway, which is the off-ramp they will take if Bernie is not the nominee. And where will that get us? The short answer is, the reelection of Trump and the likely take back of the House by Republicans. Suburban voters reject Bernie's vision of radical social upheaval. Not because his vision is undesirable, but because he rejects a gradual transition in favor of an upheaval which frightens the center. Suburban voters will likely sit out the election. America is being torn asunder by true believers on both sides.

Every time Bernie speaks about universal healthcare and Medicare for All, he wins me over. My preferred candidate was Kamala Harris, and now I prefer Elizabeth Warren. But I will vote for Bernie if he’s the nominee. I hope he doesn’t scare off suburban voters, because he will need them for us to keep the House majority and win back the Senate. Who cares if he’s a Democratic Socialist? It’s a way for him to distinguish himself from corporate Democrats.

The worst part about Bernie’s campaign are his vehement Bernie Bros (which include women), who seem to think no other candidate is worth supporting.

What too many fail to understand: Bernie appeals to many working-class Trump supporters. Those are the voters who voted twice for Obama, hoping that everything that made him seem different might also signal a disruptive approach to the systems that were failing to meet the needs of struggling blue collar Americans. Bernie still appeals to those working-class voters.

If Senator Sanders is the nominee Mr. Trump will be reelected. Mr. Sanders has weak, at best, support in communities of color. That plagued his 2016 effort and has not changed.

Nominate Senator Sanders and you elect Mr. Trump for four more years. After seeing him in revenge mode this week do you really want that?

Ideologically speaking, if you want Warren, Bernie would be a fantastic consolation prize. Don't buy into the DNC's fear-mongering over Bernie. Once again the NY Times opinion writers have to turn a negative lens on the person who seems to be the closest thing we have to a front-runner right now, Bernie Sanders. Goldberg speaks the conventional wisdom of a party establishment that has no faith in liberalism. They are worried about their futures. So many are cobbling together a living from gigs that do not provide stability, health insurance, or a living wage, and many are burdened by debt in the tens of thousands that they were encouraged by their parents, their colleges, and the banks to take on. Up until recently Sanders has seemed to put country ahead of his own ego. For those old enough to remember, President John Kennedy energized people of all ages. At the age of 35, he was a U.S. Senator, WWII hero, well educated, good looking and represented the hope and promise of a bright future. But that was a different time. Blue collar workers (steel workers where I come from) were typically unionized WWII & Korean War veterans. They had good paying jobs and benefits. Many of their children followed in their footsteps. The Democratic Party owned these families. The Republicans were still the party of the more affluent. But as the jobs of blue collar workers have been eviscerated over the last fifty years, the worker class has felt a sense of abandonment by the Democrats. When you take away the jobs and pride of a large portion of the middle class, should it be surprising that these Americans would look elsewhere for affirmation of their worth? But our problems are too large: 

First, our Constitution creates a system of government that can grossly overrepresent a minority and that is vulnerable to take-over by an autocratic president. This is a fundamental flaw that cannot be changed without rewriting the Constitution, an impossible task. 

Second, the GOP has worked for decades through its marketing and media strategies to create the current cult of Trump. This cult, which includes nearly 40% of the population, is not going away as long as Fox News exists. 

Finally, our elections are unreliable and disempowering. The problems start with state control of the election process, allowing for gerrymandering, voter suppression, and technological and process failures. Meanwhile unlimited money, advanced marketing techniques, and lack of transparency allow malign actors to manipulate the voters, turning our elections into contests of fear and hate. 

For all these reasons, elections cannot save us. Those of us who don't want to live in a Putin-style autocracy need to find another way to restore good government, rule of law, and true democracy.

Such a wonderful, searching piece. Congratulations on your work. It’s true, we are shaped by stories. Both gendered, cultural, and political, the linear journey of the hero has seemed simplistic and marginal to our experience since I left adolescence. Previous to the ‘80s, the trope of man against the world was less frequent in popular fiction than groups and families on an adventure of some kind, and often of an optimistic nature. The intense rise of capitalism in the 1980s set us digging up older stories of the lone male beset and battling the world (yes, it is always the world’s fault not his). In the realm of experimental fiction and poetry, women’s visions have been at the forefront. I’m thinking of the refracted, multiplicity of voices in Virginia Woolf and many others. TV and movies have used those written structures but lost the inclusive, diverse vision that was imagined. Violence is usually a failure of some kind—the failure to look inward and see one’s part in the story, the failure of leaders diplomatically, and the failure of basic humanity in men like the current occupant of the white house. Many multiple-voiced films are experimental and not easily available. Also, the art house films of the 50’s and 60’s did not need a happy ending. The linear journey to a happy ending is a kind of measure of force in itself—just like a smile isn’t the right response to every situation. Even popular fiction can make room for sadness, for listening to the world around us.

Was that really so bad? Yes, the female characters were limited in their occupations. They were not champions of industry or the arts or political leaders. So, the reality can be adjusted. When did that die? When did women have to battle it out with men? When did they start going to war or battling alien enemies? When did they need to be as physically violent as men? Why was it necessary?

Isn't it the times that are toxic? Must we kill the characters to tell a story? Won’t that pendulum start swinging back to reality?

Alice Hoffman writes stories about women in which the women are strong but not wolves in women's clothing. Romance writers, for all their books are denigrated, write about issues close to the hearts of many women -- and while they used to be about Dave's wife or featured hard=charging females, there's a wide range of romance novels and a wide range of issues. 

I've also worked with the hero's journey format for writing stories. Looking at it as solely a reflection of the male experience is a shallow interpretation. The call to action can be much more subtle than that found in comic-book movies -- it can be the decision to take care of a sibling on the death of a parent or even the decision to bear children. And the hero's (or, in this case, heroine's) journey spins out from there, with all the same turning points -- but not necessarily those found in adolescent male fantasies.

The female experience isn't so narrow that women need to cringe away from being Dave's wife or a hard-charging woman who takes on masculine characteristics to succeed or even being an odd old woman with 18 cats. Why do some women feel they need to narrow the female experience to one way of seeing the world?

After reading this essay I watched both seasons of The OA. It felt like watching Aikido.

Many years ago, I used to watch an Akido class and was mesmerized by the flow. Of how one partner would step to one side. Of how she would direct the other partner's force to ground. Of translating a direct motion to a circular one. It didn't feel like an attack; it felt like a dance. Of two forces finding equilibrium.

I think, a lot of Hollywood movies have become routine, monotonous, unrealistic. Definitely many recent netflix and TV shows. Everyone looks the same, acts the same, live in similar places. Male or female. Formulaic characters.
When did unrealistic comic-book or dystopian era heroes become our source of role models? Or god forbid romanticising and aggrandasing negative leads- which works to some extent, but all the time? 

There are still a lot of good moviemakers, many in international films, who see heroism in daily, real lives and people. Where women are women, in all shapes, shades, strengths and weaknesses; as well as men. 
Eg- Many UK cop/crime shows where police officers look like such, and a woman officer doesn't have to wear four inch heels, excess makeup and be dressed to the nines on her job.
I'm a big fan.  If thinking about these conflicts leads to more great TV like "The OA", then have at it!

I'd like someone to list all the descriptors for "masculine" as well as "feminine".  Then find those males and females who fulfill that overarching description (definition) wholly.

You won't come up with many Men or Women who will fill the bill.

We're battling against expectations, desires, and that pesky thing upon which Hollywood (if not entertainment in toto) rests: the epitome (of Femininity, of Masculinity), but much of what is "masculine" and "feminine" is not only determined by society, by media, by fashion, fad, and good ole capitalism, and there is much blame to lay upon Moms and Dads who start the kid out not as Male or Female, but as Masculine or Feminine.

In reality, the Masculine and the Feminine, as entities, do not exist.  They are perfections, and thus warped constructs, if not simply impossibilities, that we feed to our children from birth.

I applaud the author for noting some prominent Sci-Fi voices, such as Le Guin, who indeed world-build and create environments where there are Women and Men and a lot of Others too, and generally, there are no designated roles....outside of a society, which generally has some sort of...designated role.

So, as a society, we need to just let masculine/feminine be the fluid thing because most all of us are both in some respect, and it's no Big Deal because, as said, no one is All Masc or All Fem...which btw has nothing to do with biological gender.  Different thing. (So stop equivocating, people.)

I read this story after reading a report on the celebration of Kobe's life in another publication. I was never a fan of his after his 2003 rape accusation in Colorado. It seems to me these two stories support one another. Powerful men do what they want with the powerless women in their world. Women, on the other hand, like the sexual assault victim in Colorado choosing not to testify, cannot rise to the level of being powerful, knowing, as I assume was the case in Colorado, there will be a terrible price to pay.

Thank you for putting voice to an important, though too often hushed, thought. I hope the day comes when gender, beauty, and physical attribues, whether breast size of six-pack abs, will not matter as much as other qualifications.

This account is anecdotal.  It attempts to characterize the role of women in film by reference to prominent stereotypes.  But there are countless female roles in countless movies and reference to a few doesn't do the trick. 

The suggestion here is that objectification is the rule.   But there are countless stereotypical roles which don't objectify -- mother, daughter, sister, wife, teacher, nurse, and on and on. I suspect that the stereotypical roles far outnumber the big-breasted blondes.  But you can't win the argument with a handful of anecdotes. And that's where this piece comes up short.  There is a vast difference between roles that objectify based on appearance and roles that stereotype based on common misconceptions. And you need more than a handful of anecdotes to tell the story.

Male sexuality has a large visual element; female sexuality less so.  Movies and theater are visual media; it is easier to tell a compelling story about male sexuality in a visual medium, in part because it is easy to see and understand what attracts a man to a woman visually. You can tell a moving, funny, story about male sexuality with lots of pictures but very few words.  Female sexuality takes a lot more explaining; movies about it are necessarily wordy and dialogue driven; that works better in a novel than a movie.

Women get a better shot at singing and songwriting, where the visual is less important.  Yes, to be a successful pop star you need to make videos, and so only the beautiful need apply, but songs by and about women and female sexuality are well represented in today's music, and even in much of yesterday's.  Many of today's biggest music stars are female, and they're not successful primarily for their looks.  They certainly sing about female sexuality.  It works because the medium is primarily aural.

You are so right, Brit.  The book that comes to mind when I read this is "Uncle Tom's Cabin".  It was so real in the female characters and emotions it brought up that it actually had an effect on politics, and contributed to the polarization that led to the Civil War.  Where would we be today if that had not happened.

Why does so much "feminist" writing require the introduction of supernatural forces? It almost seems to imply that the real world that we live in, which doesn't have such forces, is not compatible with the desired feminist perspective. Is that really what's intended?

After reading this essay, I found myself thinking about movies made in the 30’s and 40’s before women were sexualized to the extent they are now. The women in many of the films (be they comedies or dramas) were very strong, and went toe to toe with their leading men ( think of Bette Davis, Joan Crawford, Katherine Hepburn, Lauren Bacall, etc.). They were smart and witty and fought back when men tried to dominate them. Sure,  sex was always under the surface and the filmmakers had to dodge the censors, but that led to some witty dialogue (see The Big Sleep).

Brava to Brit Marling on this insightful and beautiful piece.   I've been feeling what she's written about for so many years,  and most painfully since our 2016 election and especially the national events of the past week.   He is not my President. 

We need a woman in the White House,  but I'm sad to say that I don't see it happening in this country built on the macho fantasy of guns and cowboys.   

England,  Germany,  Israel and India can elect females to lead their countries,  but we can't.  Why is that?  

And while Buttigieg is appealing in his Obama-like speaking style,  he has a fraction of the governing experience of Amy Klobuchar and Elizabeth Warren.   (Amy is terrific,  and I'd love to see her manage Trump on the debate stage. )
So why is Buttigieg polling so far above these two highly qualified women?
I'm hard-pressed to reach any conclusion
other than rampant misogyny in this country.   And that makes me very sad.

And I know that I am speaking for many women and men,  because the degree of depression I've seen since the 2016 election is raging. 

Vote!

Lately streaming TV in particular has done an infinitely better job of portraying women. My favorite part of Orange is the New Black was its nuanced, textured characters we saw first through the lens of their flaws. And learned to love them from that way in. It made me realize how ravenous I was for female characters that seemed fully human. And it also reassured me that I wasn't the only one who knew women were human and someone aimed to portray that secret on screen.

I formed my ideas of what women were supposed to be as a kid based largely on what I was on TV. It was discouraging. I remember being fully aware that no woman I saw seemed to reflect who I knew I was. So was hard to imagine growing up to join the real-life band of wives, girlfriends as strong female leads available to me when I didn't see myself in them at all. That's why this is important, and she is so right, how we shape our narratives determines a lot. The good news is, the truth is so much better than the lies we tell. In real life, women come in every form you can imagine, and many you can't. Every advancement we make in telling that feels like exhilarating release.

Ms Marling,

I'm so glad that you became a writer, director, producer instead of another actress forced to adopt the roles that we already have.  I'm excited by the fact that you are in the role of creating and telling the stories that will open our minds into new ways of recognizing heroism. Thank you so much for this, Brit Marling. Such a cogent picture of how women are longing to change the story--aware that unless we do, we may not survive. Our war on poverty, on cancer, on drugs--an economy waged as war with towns and farms looking like war zones....Can we imagine stories without violent drama and climactic satisfaction? Read Ursula LeGuin's delightful essay, The Carrier Bag Theory of Fiction. A more circular plot, with many sundry heroes huddled around a fire, in danger of....? each other? the weather? a stubborn violent king?--that's where we are. Violence is addictive, a symptom of deadening our deepest desires. Violence is exciting, but never lasts the way intimate relationships can--but if a man is devoted to his loves, his soulmate or children or friends, real friends,, does that make him a wuss? Endanger his being a man? I'm thankful for Marling's co-creator Zal Batmanflij and his generation, more complicated than my own.

Ms. Marling rightly offers the spectrum of humanity, the beautify of what each person in their earthly construction brings to the table; but, with respect, she doesn't offer us the nuanced approach I believe she possesses.

There is no benefit in promoting violence, particularly as we cannot escape it, both important and sensationalized, in the news (especially where it is important for betterment, such as knowledge of sex trafficking).

(In other words -- a bit of a plant by her publicist, and frankly not up to the usual NYT standard for pieces about issues this important.) If you really want your readers to miss your (ostensible) point, bury it underneath a confessional, mildly overwrought, didactic tone, and make sure you include some obligatory self-revelation about bi-fluidity (more power to you) and victimization. (Common and inexcusable as DV might be -- my own obligatory disclosure being that I prosecuted such cases at one time, so I'm hardly unsympathetic.) respectfully- and I mean FULL PROPS for your work and being in the trenches- have to disagree with the premise that every step in expanding our definition of the role of women does not mean we are denying our femininity if it veers into tropes and traits designated to men. I have to disagree

I know a woman who embodies everything Ms. Marling is yearning to find. She has a type of power that I have rarely known. Her power is in her goodness and her empathy and her emotional intelligence. She not only makes people around her feel better, she makes them want to be better.

My friend has a job where she was the lowest status person in the place. Brit, if you're reading this, call my producer. I have been a Hollywood screenwriter for three decades. My protagonists have been both men and women, none of them stuck in conventional plots. I gnashed my teeth when reading your piece, not because I disagreed with you but because a story I've been trying to tell for over a decade could be the "solution" to the imagined future of female-centered stories. Mine is quite simply the story of a woman going through the most earthly and unique event of her life, the birth of a child, while working in the International Space Station. This unprecedented human event highlights not only the courage and love of this astronaut but her connection to every other woman who ever gave birth. While it is fiction, some might say science-fiction, the story is based in realism. It could actually happen tomorrow. There are many reasons multiple outlets have passed on the script, but I always suspect that it is because it is much closer to your vision of a female future in film than it is to the cookie-cutter male-driven films we have now. Or maybe it's that I am a male and I'm not allowed to write such stories. In any event, take a look at my script and see if some of what you're looking for is there.  Best, Doug

I often think about the structure of ancient myth, and how those structures have filtered down to define and confine what is the essential male hero’s quest. That quest, in a nutshell, is simple: go out and get, and bring it back. This structure is biological. It is a male hunting story, a story of men going out to get food, killing (or not) some sort of animal, and then eating it. 

So it is difficult to find the ancient structures and possibilities of a woman’s story in that vision of the hero’s quest. Women were not, by and large, participants in that story. But the absence of women in that hero’s quest points to other places to look. What was the woman’s heroic quest in ancient society? What vital biological function did she provide? 

One easy answer is fertility: not as a vessel for seed, but as a creative force of regeneration, brought about through pain, pleasure, sacrifice, and above all else, compassion. That I think is one place to start searching for the woman’s story. Whereas the men’s quest has all the same requirements—the pleasure, the pain, the sacrifice—a woman’s story substitutes domination for compassion. And compassion is just as strong as domination. While the man dominates the weak, the woman cares for the weak and helps it grow strong. 

This is an easy answer. It doesn’t take much digging to find the Paleolithic fertility goddesses littering the world. But why not start there?

That's why the novel is called "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?" Strictly speaking, we're not even sure Deckard is human in the original writing. He might be an android programmed to kill other androids. This would explain his unhealthy obsession with normality and "live" animals. Needless to say, his empathy is often misdirected. "Electric Sheep" absolutely meant to question what it means to be human regardless of gender.

The double standard that exists in real life, in which women have to be twice as competent as their male counterparts in order to get the same level of respect, exists in fiction as well. So while a male hero can be flawed, can have weaknesses as well as strengths - can be, in other words, a human being - a female hero is too often expected to be perfect at everything. I think one of the biggest problems is that female writers feel pressured to get something, anything on paper. Doesn’t give enough time to let the story marinate and become what it really wants (needs) to be. 

As a female writer quietly plucking away at short stories and screenplays, I’ve struggled in the past to know how far is too far with my female characters. How believable is this strong female lead? What are men going to think about her? But when we ask ourselves these kinds of questions, we’re still perceiving ourselves through the eyes of men. Until we arrive at a point where we can honestly say “I don’t care what you think because this is my story and I’ve revised it a million times now, and I’ve let it simmer, and I know I’m telling it the way it needs to be told,” then we really don’t have a finished story worthy of publishing/production, do we?

Because so much about writing has to do with getting over the fear of being judged. It’s harder for women, but it’s necessary. 

So here’s hoping Greta Gerwig wins the Oscar for Adapted Screenplay since she was snubbed in directing. Her story is what needs to be rewarded anyway, because the story is the key.

"Masculine modalities of power."

That seems to me the crux of the issue. Are there any other modalities? Isn’t that an iron rule of human societies that to rise through human structures, you need large amounts of ruthlessness, drive, over-confidence, selfishness, domination, willingness to use some amount of violence? Sadly, you don’t climb up and stay in power by being empathetic, sensitive, listening, kind, competent, and having people reward you for those. I think that’s a pipe dream to hope otherwise. That’s why I tend to think that the lack of women at positions of power in human structures also reflects, on top of a bias against women, a bias against people displaying the latter qualities - bias which can also affect men, but women tend to display the latter traits more than the former (even if there is a lot of overlap, of course). And why women in power today (in reality or in stories) are essentially men in women’s clothes, as Brit Marling notes. 

In short, it’s not that we only celebrate masculine modalities of power - it’s that power amongst humans is what it is, and perhaps men are more often geared towards seeking it than women. I have little hope that it will change anytime soon.

Excellent piece. it gave rise to these further thoughts: All traits and characteristics are present in all people. Only the mixture of them in each person is unique; that's a given. It's tempting for the sake of narrative clarity, to go along with how society attributes these, e. g., women are holistic, men are compartmental, men instruct, women transform. It's tempting, for the promotion of a necessary shift in power-sharing, to focus on gender. Yet doing so, exclusively, obscures a paramount underlying current human misconception which is that we are still in a naked fight for survival. Society, hence, hails the qualities it considered most needed for said survival -- brawn, ability to dominate, cunning, ruthlessness. What we need is a declaration of the end of the era of survival and the beginning of the era of life affirming creativity and vision. And in this new era what we need to hail more than anything else is the one trait that is responsible for getting us this far in our evolution: our inborn mutuality that leads to cooperation, sharing, and altruism. Where gender needs to be brought into the discussion is to support an initiative that stops training men-identified individuals out of these inherent competencies.

Brit Marling has discussed these same issues elsewhere in more detail, and they are worth a moment of search engine time to find them.

She discusses this as unwilling, coerced "consent", and as rape being the big trauma constantly assigned to and inflicted on women in this way.

Yet abuse of "consent" by those with the economic yes/no power of a gatekeeper goes much further than women, much further than rape. It is a constant. It is what gatekeeping does. 

Those who say we must have gatekeepers to make things work at all imply that all we need do is perfect the people who are gatekeepers. If only they would never abuse their power. If only they'd be nice to everyone and always make the right choices. Nonsense. People are not perfectible. Power corrupts.

You give such power, and you give corruption. It is Lord Acton's truth, “Power tends to corrupt and absolute power corrupts absolutely. Great men are almost always bad men."

We have the wealth and position of deep development as a society to provide for everyone the basics, so that no gatekeeper can deny food, shelter, medical care, basic security.

There may always be big employers driving a big economy, and gatekeepers to it, but we need not give them the power over economic security or safety. That is a choice. We empower that extreme of gatekeeping.

That is the truth Brit Marling touches here.

If older (60s-70s,) secondary female characters aren't comfortable grandmothers, they often engage in inappropriate flirting with younger male characters (i.e. they cannot be imagined beyond the maternal or sexual aspects of their characters.) 

2) The Chilling Adventures of Sabrina: there are three main roles for women in their 40s and 50s—well-developed interesting characters; one is dumpy; one has great costumes; two are competently ambitious. They all have relationships at some point in the series, but these are recounted from their own female perspectives, fit into the overall plot, and are just one aspect of well-rounded characters who are up to all sorts of things.

I have had feelings about women's roles in films like Ms. Marling's for years, particularly around what she calls the Strong Female Lead. 

When Wonder Woman came out it was hailed as having at its center a female character that was a role model for young girls. I thought the exact opposite. The reason we, or at least some of us, want more women in positions of power is precisely because they don't behave like men. Wonder Woman solves her problems by beating up or killing the bad guys, attractively and in her underwear. Despite the skimpy costume, that's a stereotypically male way of dealing with things, and not what I would want the young girls of today to think they need to become as women.

"It's difficult for us to imagine feminity itself - empathy, vulnerability, listening - as strong." 
Those words truly warmed my heart. Thank you so so much. This is exactly what I've been feeling lately. It is so exhausting trying to fit in the ideal of the strong and sexy, clever but not cheeky woman.

These are the very reasons I quit going to the movies or even watching them on TV. The only film I've seen at the theater in the past several years has been Little Women. Before that it was Hidden Figures. In the 70s, when I came of age and wanted to act (for the very reasons Brit cites), I was already frustrated with the roles written for women. I remember working on a scene from "In the Boom-Boom Room," and not having a clue about how to play the woman's role (I think she was a stripper). It was so very alien to me. Then I played Annie Sullivan in The Miracle Worker—a woman who bucked the patriarchy in Helen Keller's own home in order to let Helen live fully—and felt right at home. I am glad Brit is shaping narratives now, even if they are speculative, not getting shot or stabbed in some man's fantasy of real life. Brava.
