Hello! American in Beijing right now with my husband. We have decided to stay put as our dog needs us and we would not want to put the burden of taking care of our dog on anyone else right now. Also, we would not want to risk exposing anyone in the states as there seems to be quite a few people who are afraid of the unknown. We are looking forward to the day when we can have some normalcy again but we have to continue to remind ourselves that there are worse situations out there and to count our blessings. Please keep all of us in your thoughts and prayers.

I have a job in China but I left. Easy decision because as an ESL teacher I had two months holiday and was out before the virus was even discussed. I have no idea when I will go back.
Staying or leaving is a hard decision. For all, there is the costs of a flight, abandonment of possessions or continuing rent payments. Many could lose a business they have built up over years or lose a job. Coming back home could mean paying for a hotel for months while trying to find a new job. It is not just a quick trip to the airport.
Staying in China though without a useful purpose feels like being a burden. I struggle in the Chinese health system in normal times and can't imagine how I would fare without fluency in the overcrowding of an epidemic.

I live in Zhengzhou, in a huge apartment complex, with 8 towers. All the entrances are locked except the main one, where there are two police officers. You now have to have a government ticket residence there to leave or enter. I got mine this morning. I needed to go out to get bottled water and food. You can only go out and come back between 9am and 12pm.

Zhengzhou is huge, and I live downtown on the biggest street. Everyone is closed except for one supermarket in my neighborhood, so this morning it was really crowded. Last week I would go at 5am, when no one was there.

Really, all there is to do is stay home, wash your hands a lot, and hope for the storm to pass. I should say people at the store were really polite and calm.

I should note I check Google a lot and there is no reporting on any cases in Zhengzhou, or none that I can find. Of course, I check daily.

I enjoyed your article. I too, am here with my family. I have also been in wechat groups with many others staying - and there are a huge variety of reasons that people have - all of them good reasons and all very personal. For us, we have a visa thing that needs to be sorted first, but in addition to that, we've lived here for 6 years. The thought of just leaving our home, our belongings, our community, our jobs, indefinitely seems like a kind of crazy thing to do, especially when you're in a city where the cases of the virus are so low - for now. The thought of carting my two kids (4 and 5 years old) on a 14 hour flight to the US and stay with our elderly family - and risk bringing the virus with us - or staying in a hotel indefinitely somewhere racking up a bill (especially with a 14 day quarantine on top of it), does not sound appealing. But of course, I worry too, and we may change our minds once we get the logistics of the visas sorted out. Hang in there!

I live in Zhengzhou, in a huge apartment complex, with 8 towers. All the entrances are locked except the main one, where there are two police officers. You have to have a government ticket residence there to leave or enter. I got mine this morning. I needed to go out to get bottled water and food. You can only go out and come back between 9am and 12pm.

Zhengzhou is huge, and I live downtown on the biggest street. Everyone is closed except for one supermarket in my neighborhood, so this morning it was really crowded. Last week I would go at 5am, when no one was there.

Really, all there is to do is stay home, wash your hands a lot, and hope for the storm to pass. I should say people at the store were really polite and calm.

This article and the comments to it has truely lifted my feelings. I'm a Japanese mom whose 37-year-old son had come back from Shanghai last week but will go back again next Monday. He works for a Jap firm with over 100 Chinese employees. Business will probably not resume but he is going back with suitcases and bags filled with face masks. There is also a demand for smaller ones to fit ladies and small children. Sending them by mail or delivery is hopeless. A few boxes of masks would not make much difference, but he needs to tell his coworkers he cares for them. I just pray for his safety.

Point of information - I understand there is a habit of people spitting in public in Chinese cities. Is there any indication that this practice has furthered the spread of the virus, among other means of transmission?

Not to presume, and I'm certainly not poking fun, but I'll bet there are a lot of Times readers who would love to spend their days lounging in pajamas, having groceries delivered.

If only there were a way of making money at it.

There are good reasons to stay or go, but if you base your decision on health risks, it is essential that the reported figures be reliable. Authoritarian regimes default to obfuscation on minor matters because secrecy is essential to controlling the levers of society. Investors, scientists, diplomats and others may choose to believe data the Chinese government offers in their respective fields of interest, but the risk of relying on epidemiological data in the midst of a an epidemic is too high.

I am scared to death of the spread of this virus. People of my age (post mid 70s) simply do not have the defenses to survive. Yet we are among the most productive in the intellectual world. I'm working on my third book, this time about how the warming climate has adversely impacted the 2nd largest stratovolcano in the Cascades—Mount Adams in southern Washington State.
Darryl Lloyd

Chinese people have gotten used to managed existence; a bargain where they follow the rules and the leaders provide safety, financial and food security.  The system has been working so far due to good growth rates and the communist party's muscle flexing and hard bargaining to accumulate from the global marketplace.  The virus has brought the place to a stand still and is testing the system as people expect the virus to be booted out.  This expectation may be a monster that may eat up the master if the virus goes on for a long time.

This couple should be aware that if they do leave, they will be quarantined on some USAF base for at least two weeks with others who may have been exposed. I’m not sure what I’d do. But I’d probably leave. Ms Huang is right that if the infrastructure goes, she and her husband could be caught in a real-life horror show. Yeah. I’d leave.

I honestly feel for you and pray this ends soon.

 But my real question is: why weren’t you writing op/ed columns about open air live animal markets before this outbreak? The hideous animal cruelty and health risks to the rest of the world posed by these inhuman practices surely outweigh the cultural practiceof eating snakes (linked by scientists to this outbreak)and domesticated dogs. Enough is enough.

My spouse and I and our two children live in Shanghai. There is no lockdown here. You are free to venture out as far and often as you see appropriate. There are relatively very few cases of infection, considering how massive the city is. Many people, including us, prudently minimize time at crowded indoor spaces, but a walk around the neighborhood or to a nearby park is perfectly safe. Sunshine, (relatively) fresh air and exercise are key inputs to staying healthy, and do wonders for one's mood and outlook.

I am in Beijing and reluctantly leaving for the UK this morning. (8th Feb). Leaving behind friends and colleuagues is not easy and to see the effects of the virus on the economy and people' lives is stunning.
My choice to leave comes from an awareness that, should I become ill and, therefore confined / isolated, I could rely on getting the resources I would need (Food and meds getting delivered) compared to how locals would have family to support them. 
As for the virus itself, I honestly do not fear that any more than I would flu or pneumonia; both of which I have had, and recovered from.
My heart goes out to all those living in fear and isolation in China and I hope to be back in China at the next available opportunity.

One way to analyze stay-versus-leave is to ask how risky it is for someone outside China to go to China, or for someone in China outside Hubei to go to Hubei.

Going to Hubei sounds like a terrible idea; going to China sounds like a very bad idea.

Then one might identify and analyze the risks associated with leaving Hubei and China. Might one be stranded on the way out of Hubei/China? Might one catch the disease on the way out and be quarantined or hospitalized? If traveling with family, what happens if one member comes down with coronavirus? What if various forms of international transportation will no longer accept passengers with passports from China, as has just happened with Princess Cruise Lines, and may happen with some airlines? What if certain destinations are no longer open to Chinese?

Perhaps some NYT readers are already working on a risk-assessment algorithm to deal with such decisions and can share their wisdom by commenting here, or by cooperating with NYT writers in preparing an article.

Deciding whether to leave or stay is an intensely personal process, informed by often sketchy information. Based on living and traveling in third-world countries, my experience has been that it is better to leave before conditions deteriorate and threats to life and limb increase to levels that local and national governments are unable to manage.

For me the fact that the US Embassy and most US nationals have been evacuated is a pretty good sign that it’s time to go.

You are young and healthy, however, consider what will happen to the medical system if cases in Shanghai increase to hundreds or thousands, fear takes over, hospitals are flooded and there is no oxygen or medically supportive care. Then, as the epidemic increases, food becomes scarce. 

I would leave ASAP. You are the lucky ones. My heart breaks for anyone who cannot get out.

Incredible column.  The inevitable argument in dire conditions-i.e. keep moving or huddle down.  (Sounds eerily like an argument from WWZ.)  But in any calamity (war, pestilence, natural disaster), people are moving.  China was experiencing capital flight before Wuhan.  Undoubtedly it is continuing.  So the obvious questions.  Who is moving (if anyone), where are they going and why?  Follow the wealth and power, and those that have it, in their private decisions.  It usually provides a significant amount of answers to questions.

"The virus is very good at math." Indeed, I have thought the same thing. The numbers they are reporting do not add up; I think they know that if they report a worsening fatality rate, their ability to control the situation will spiral rapidly out of control. A virus that kills 2 out of 100 feels very different than one that kills, say, 20 or 30. Who knows what the truth is; we won't know until free countries begin to truly learn about the virus.

I would leave if you can. If things get worse you might reach the point where you no longer have the luxury of choice, and an easy exit may no longer be available.

I'm on the other side of the planet with well stocked emergency supplies and I'm still nervous about what might happen if things get worse.
Should one of them fall ill, they will be draining resources from an already overwhelmed healthcare system.

I would recommend that you depart now, before the United States closes its borders to people coming from China, or before China closes its borders like in the olden days of the Maoists. The first would be done to protect Americans; the second to protect China's potential for rejoining the world community after this public health, governmental, and cultural debacle.  May the virus mutate in a good direction, and not a deadlier one.

Talk to anyone who has lived through the Cultural Revolution, as I have, and you will have no illusions about what the Chinese government is capable of doing to its own Han population, much less the Tibetans or the Uighurs.
Having lived in Beijing I wouldn’t trust any info from the government any more than I could pick up and throw one cadre.

I am an American, retired teacher. I am married to a Chinese national so I spend half the year or more here in Nanning Guangxi Province. 

The streets are deserted, all schools and many businesses are closed. I wonder how long some of these establishments can hold out with no income. The restaurant industry has been annihalated. Who in their right mind will eat food prepared by strangers? For the vast number of retail establishments the business model is foot traffic. Will people pay tuition to closed schools? Is a collapse of the Chinese economy a possibility?

 Apparently, face masks are now mandatory but none can be had so I have been making my own. 1.3 billion masks per day are required in all of China.

I intend to wait it out. The alternative that awaits is, like the author said, being cooped up in a closed space with strangers for half a day and not knowing what awaits me on the other end. Can I even get out if wanted to? First I would have to fly from Nanning to Shanghai or Beijing. The Chinese airline industry is not dependable right now. Besides, I will not run out on my wife.

This sounds like a tough call. If you look at it from other outbreaks like SARS and the Avian flu, chances are that this will too pass. Is this the Spanish flu? Probably not since the cases outside the region are low. But if it were the Spanish flu, then it doesn't sound like anybody will be safe regardless of where we try to hide. It sounds like you are doing the correct thing rather than getting on a plane and taking more chances with a long flight. Plus as you said, you are young and healthy. So it appears that your risk is lower compared to others. That being said, you are brave and you should do what feels right. I know that as a parent, I would want you home yesterday. Good luck and let's hope this is contained soon. I am so sorry for you all others who are going through this.

A thoughtful article about being (relatively) privileged in stressful times.  

The author notes that "we plebes are not privy to the whole truth."  However, I'm pretty sure that if one lives on the 23rd floor of a luxury building, have all one's meals delivered by nameless worker bees, and hold U.S. passports, one is not exactly a plebeian.

I'm pretty sure I would stay - being much more scared of flying and then spending weeks on a US military base (now required) than being in my comfy Shanghai high-rise with delivery (not fair).   But that's maybe denial and naivete.  One must also consider that the death rate is likely around 2-3%, so there's a very high survival rate.  Though I'm not sure whether that points to staying or going...… 
Very tough call

Wonderful essay; thanks.  'Hang in there' is my suggestion.  My spouse and I--and our 11-month-old baby--were in Taichung, Taiwan, during the SARS outbreak in 2003.  We, too, felt anxious as the situation worsened, but decided to stick it out.  Taiwan is not the PRC, of course, and there are important differences in the reliability of the news about the spread of the virus, but it's the virus that'll git ya, and so far the virus doesn't seem to be coming for young, healthy people like you and your spouse. Know that your compatriots back in Mei-guo are thinking about you, and maybe stock up a bit more on fresh water? No sense in upending your lives for this; it'll pass when the weather warms.
Sounds like incipient cabin fever to me. I live in Shanghai, too. Get outside and go for a walk. There’s little to fear and you’ll feel much better. This too, shall pass.

What struck me was the reference to possible shortages. If that's the case, doesn't it seem right that any healthy people who have the option to leave do so, so as to leave all possible resources for those who can't?
I understand the fear of the author. It doesn't make sense given the numbers we are hearing, but can we trust the CPC's numbers? I would be scared too.

I agree; traveling is the danger.  Or, to be more blunt, being around a mass of people is the true danger.

Of course, being around a mass of people is always a potential danger, so go figure.

The author captured my mood, even though I am 12 time zones away. I’m waiting for news about when the Spring semester will start and I will return to China... the city I teach in is far from Hubei, we lived on the outskirts of the city in a closed campus setting. My family wants me to stay, safe in Canada... but I enjoy my job, my colleagues, my students and the joys of discovery living in China. I relate to the author’s suspended animation... I thought I would be home a few weeks and wouldn’t need to get used to the cold... only bought a dozen eggs, a small coconut milk for my coffee. Now I try to walk in the cold each day, reconnect with friends, volunteered for a political campaign, working on a paper, editing others... I’m keeping busy. 

With more unknowns and rumours than knowns and facts makes life very strange. A colleague is in Wuhan, I’m keeping his one kg of timbits cereal safe... I can only imagine the hardship, his descriptions are understated. I see his posts at 5 am on wechat, I know he feels helpless. I want to do something, but what? Buy masks to send? Send sanitizer? Maybe I should send the cereal...

Wishing you safety. Having spent some time in China, I think it is one of the most amazing countries on earth.  It's just so sad that the government filters news to its people and comes down so hard on those who speak out or seek information. It's not necessary for the government to exert such control over information when Chinese patriotism is so high. Blocking access to information does not correlate with patriotism.  In this case the lack of information and government control has proven harmful to put it mildly.
This reads like dystopian fiction, but is real life.

My wife is in the Southern City of Nanning (pop- 5 million) located in Guangxi Autonomous Region. 
My wife reports that the city buses and taxis are no longer running due to the virus. 
Face masks are rationed to just 3 masks and you have to wait in line for over an hour to get them . 
My wife also reports Nanning Police are ordering people back to their homes if they are not wearing face masks. 
The only time she goes out is to buy food from a local market. Otherwise the family stays home . 
I wanted to send her boxes of face masks, but with Chinese customs working at a snails pace . It could take over a month. Then there’s the problem of theft. Due to the current high demand for face masks.
This article is very affecting. My heart seemed to rise to my throat and ended in my gut. Thank you.

It is telling that this couple is able to stay in their homes, safe from the virus, but they still rely on couriers to deliver their food and other basic needs. These couriers puts themselves at risk of infection because they can't afford to stop working. What a stark reminder that when epidemics, natural disasters, and the worst of climate change come our way, it is the working class who suffers most.

From Taiwan News comes a secretly filmed video from inside the much vaunted 1000 patient hospitals that were stood up in only ten days. These were meant to showcase how fast the CCP could react to the crises in a way that the West could not.  The "hospital" rooms don't have electrical outlets or oxygen lines, have bars on the windows and their doors have locks on the exterior that can only be opened from the outside.  It is surmised that these already built prefabricated building were meant for the internment camps of Xinjiang where over one million Uyghurs are being held in prison like conditions. The contractor making the video can be heard saying "Once you get in, you can't get out."

Douthat’s opinion piece could be critiqued for being too long, but cutting it much would lessen its effect and leave out a number of concepts to ponder:  Is “stagnation” really quite a different thing from “decadence?”  Likewise as to “stalemate.”  Neither of these states bears the evil-like darkness and negativity of “decadence,” notwithstanding Douthat’s reworking of that word’s definition.  It’s length reveals a profound reflection, and takes its author out of the sloganeering of customary-length opinions.  The primary element that counters his conclusion that good might come from “his” decadence is the continuing efforts of a host of people to disrupt the normal process of democracy to further their own ends.  To get any ladder out of this kind of decadence requires a counter-host of people in opposition to those ends.  Where are they?

Ross could have simplified his abstruse thought world by saying: "I am neo-Hegel. Thesis. Antithesis. Synthesis. Mess." If you're going to go big, I'd opt for Lloyd deMause's description of the evolution of psycho-history: the different personality types that have evolved over time. Where "My conclusion from a lifetime of psychohistorical study of childhood and society is that the history of humanity is founded upon the abuse of children." Something to sink your teeth into.

“Decadence”? Look no further than the far-reaching unmasking of religious institutions, the supposed moral forces in Western societies, revealing their staggering hypocrisy and profound evil rot. I’m particularly talking, of course, about Catholicism and Evangelical Christianity. They are done as the arbiters of conduct for us. As irrelevant as the National Prayer Breakfast.

A very Catholic analysis Ross, do this, do that.

It's time for a revolution.

The Gordon Gecko aspirational model promoted by Republicans and Democrats over the course of the past 50 years has crashed and burned. Good riddance.

Onward Christian soldiers.
Hmmm.  So bring on the monarchy and institute mandatory church attendance, but at the right house of worship, of course.
People aren't starting businesses or having kids because health care and daily life is TOO EXPENSIVE, Ross.
The saddest realization of our descent into an American dystopia under the rule of a mad king is that we've done this to ourselves. Somewhere, the Founders must be weeping.

I addressed a comment directly to Ross Douthat, a simple comment asking him to pay someone to take a bus from Boston MA and write in detail about that experience.

Then fly the same person to Sweden to take a Greyhound bus trip of the same length between Linköping and Gothenburg.

I have just received to extraordinary, for me unbelievable replies.

One by John in upstate New York tells me that because the USA has different demographics than does Sweden, the USA cannot have decent public transportation. He simply states that, no explanation at all.

The other, by Carl Bumba, I quote completely: "I agree with your conclusion, but your argument is unfair. Public transportation, especially bus travel, has different roles in the two societies (unfortunately)."

Will Ross Douthat tell me the same if he happens to read my comment? Will he tell me exactly what these two men tell me.

I thank both of them because they reveal something I never learned in the 62 years I lived in the United States in 5 different states.

I never learned that the United States, the richest country in the world, cannot provide decent public transportation because 1) USA demographics differ from those of Sweden, 2) Bus travel has a different role in the USA than in Sweden.

I thought that buses are intended to provide a means for an individual to get from point A to point B. Carl tells me that is not true, but he fails to tell me the purpose of having buses in America.

Only-NeverInSweden.blogspot.com

You ignore the progress made on renewable energy in this period. At the time we put man on the moon, the thought that we could power entire industries, automobiles, homes, from an energy source that is basically free and entirely equitably distributed around the globe was barely a pipe dream. Even now the only thing that stops this from becoming a world wide reality is politics.

A really excellent and thought-provoking read, thanks. However I think that we should reassess, relative to a sub-plot here, and not conflate low birthrates and slow or no economic growth with stagnation in any form. Stable or even better, a declining population coupled with a sustainable economy would be a great gift for humanity. It's just possible that giving up our expansionist thinking and action could both save the planet and release energy to revitalize our cultures.

Restlessness made many of us insane. It's like the immune system that attacks the body because it can't find something real to be inflamed about. It's addicted to inflammation.

We premeditate total opposition to people among the most similar to us in the world, pre-emptively justify outrageous rudeness to them, and turn play combat into a minor religion. If only Twitter warriors volunteered instead.

What if these comically small decades of trends continue indefinitely? By that reasoning, we can panic about every trend!

The amazing, touching, happily human thing is that we all have decided, furiously, not to give up. Every political zeitgeist is treated as more pivotal and unique than the last, just like the last one was, but the US electorate is starving for nothing so much as a national project to pour ourselves into. The only major flaw in Ross' analysis is that Obama nearly pulled off total overhaul of American healthcare. We have screamed for more - two elections powered by hope led to two more powered by audacity, which are nearly the same thing.

We are timid enough to be stable, and passionate enough not to like it very much. It only took a few years for Trump to take over. The lesson there isn't how dedicated we are to Trump - it's how much we want to be dedicated to something. We sure could use someone who can distract us with a good national project, while fixing up some of our institutions meanwhile. Hey - we have about 400 years yet to find Ross' renaissance!

It is way too early for such a conclusion. Further, it is the events of the 20th century that has shaped our present. Here in the United States we passed many laws, programs and initiatives hoping to make things better, however we held no one accountable. What resulted?

The consequence is frustration and the deterioration of initiative. Our leaders, politicians, were not and are not held accountable. This situation was exasperated  because of Citizens United and Gerrymandering.

Citizens United created a situation where our votes went to the highest bidder. Gerrymandering made it possible for those purchased politicians to carve up congressional districts in a manner that optimizes control over what laws are passed and enacted.

Washington is not held accountable "for the people and by the People" to form a more perfect union. Instead, our politicians seek the goals and objectives of their large financial contributors.

Accountability should matter.

I would add to the excellent writing here one additional aspect of decadence. It is a pervasive belief that someone else will solve the problems of today. The boomers who marched, sat-in, shut down campuses and activated themselves for civil and equal rights now wait for someone else to pick up the torch. The challenges didn't end when Nixon waved good bye to all of us. But, judging by how many of us decided to desist rather than persist, we are where we are today. 

True, the torch has yet again has passed to a new generation, but it certainly seems much dimmer now than it did then. The same cannot be said though for the problems.

Eloquent, thoughtful, provocative are among the words that came to mind as I read it.  It is certainly worthy of mulling over and reading more than once.  But for me, the critical words are found at the very beginning below the title.

"The real story of the West in the 21st century is one of stalemate and stagnation." 

The critical words here are "the West" which I think of more as the "North Atlantic".   Wittingly or not, this sets up a boundary and one that I suspect could be appropriate.

I have worked and often lived all over the world for more than five decades.  I find that nations internally disrupted are often divided into two groups - one that is frightened of the future and desperately struggles to return to a past that is gone forever and one that is looking forward to the future and frightened of missing out on taking part.

Those who look to the future for inspiration will have a hand in creating that future.  Those who look to the past for inspiration won't and will have to make do with what is left over.

Is not decadence the reward of success?  

I believe Mr. Douthat has used the wrong word.  

Is this not the Age of Senescence, similar to the End of History?  We are ending on a low note, not the high note of success.

This is a terrific, thought provoking piece. I can feel the decadence but never really conceptualized it as this does. 

I would hope that the book will delve into the question of how we got to where we are. I would venture that it was a confluence of many things, the 50s prosperity, the 60s permissiveness, Vietnam, the end of the Cold War without a WW III, the decay of our national government, ending the draft, the growth of the media and entertainment, trickle down economics, the debasing of education, Clinton’s affair and so on. 

I was in the C Suite (didn’t call it that then) of the world’s second largest computer company in the 80s. We built things and advanced technology in a real way.  From the big mainframes to the PC. Today, we think that Twitter and Facebook and WeWork are real advances. Back in those old days there was a real partnership between the government and industry to foster technological advances. Many of our greatest advances came out of the Space Program. Now the goals are set by venture capitalists trying to make a quick buck. We have lost all sense of an industrial policy to guide our way. It’s all Willy nilly and short term money driven. 

To get going again will require structural change in both the public and private sectors. That will be hard.

Bravo!  This may be the most insightful column I've ever read by Mr. Douthat.  It echos many things which I have seen both personally and from a distance for some time.

Perhaps the most personal was when he spoke of the younger generations lack of wanderlust.  By my mid-thirties I had lived across the US and had major career accomplishments as well as a family.  My children conversely are the most unadventurous, unambitious people imaginable.  A malaise of decadent lack of curiosity  and direction appears to pervade their friends lives as well.

Well conceived and well written for an enlightening Sunday reading Sir.

The internet also speeds decadence by making information so easily available by well-optimized search algorithms. So now, scholarly breadth is increasingly optional. The consequence is a shallowness of knowledge that is ill suited to effective understanding and problem-solving. Likewise, the rise of machine-learning approaches reduce reliance on human intuition and creative thought. Hopefully, these are growing pains that we will eventually work past, but they manifest decadence for the moment.

Mr. Douthat's remarks on the decadent economy ring true in so many ways.  The lords of the internet seem particularly skilled in providing us with what we don't need, and also leave us progressively unpracticed in determining, as a society, what we can actually use.  Venture capitalists aren't very good at servicing society, since their chief goal is to acquire more capital.  When I ride my bicycle along perfectly graded pathways that converge and blend with auto and commuter train traffic here in Portland, I have the at least momentary sense that funds, ideas, expertise, and needs have been well distributed throughout my urban built environment.  It takes all kinds of people working together, face-to-face, and yes, planning for the future, to make that happen.  The internet hardly ever feels that way.  The fact is that if our schools were beautiful and fully provisioned, for example, our young people would see the real world as a far more promising and convincing place and be less likely to give credence to a tech economy that does so few of the things that society actually need technology to do.

I find the omission of any mention of climate change interesting in an article the spans the arc of the last 20 years of decadence.  Is the embrace of it, as a cause, an example of bored directionless wealth?  Is it's denial an example of maybe a more self interested bored wealth?  And could it also be a poster boy for our inability to go big  in the 21st century, as Douthat surmises, given that climate change is mostly relegated to movie trailer like headlines, on both sides generally. ?  Somehow, the subject perfectly bookends the 21st century so far and arguably as an example of us being, like The Decadent Society, "a victim of its own success."

Interesting.  What I get from this Op-Ed is a desire for the sustainable decadence described towards the end.  I do see one major innovation currently being perfected, though—the movement towards solar power instead of fuel-based technologies (steam, internal combustion, etc).  At any rate, I can anticipate that the effects of climate change will provide us the need and intensity to innovate in the not-so-distant future.

Douthart seems to think that somehow shucksters and con-men and capitalist speculation are somehow specific to our generation and our condition. But look at the birth of L.A. or the gold rush as bubbles in their own right, founded on marketing and lies and over-promises. The idea that this is somehow a more 'decadent' era seems a flimsy theory based on a highly simplistic reading of recent history.

The real story here is that we face the one of the greatest challenges of our lifetimes in changing our fossil-fueled economy to one that will allow our children and grandchildren to have a future on this planet. There are so many great solutions and ideas-- from Elon Musk's solar roofs and electric vehicles (granted well-marketed! and over-promising, but somehow he's not included here..) to new green infrastructures that can help adapt cities to rising sea levels and provide an expanded public realm. We just need to adopt these ideas, fund them in the same ways that previous generations funded trans-continental railroads and the suburbs and highways and sent a man to the moon. Thanks for that monumental generalization. 

What I see, if I may indulge in my own monumental generalization, is a divide between two types of Americans:

1. Reactionary people clinging to fantasies of a past Golden Age that never existed except for a lucky minority. 

These people tend to fear innovation, the other, and the unknown. They're prone to authoritarian sympathies and seek a false sense of security in unquestioning allegiance to absolutes. They need authorities who tell them what it's safe to think.

In their fear, often sublimated and unacknowledged, they're not content to find security in their own adherence to a set of beliefs; they must impose their beliefs on others, because the mere visibility of different beliefs and behaviors threatens their illusion of security.

2. Open-minded people humble enough to acknowledge their own limitations but not paralyzed by the awareness of those limits. 

They respond to that awareness by seeking more knowledge. This disposition affords them a sense of enthusiasm; the learning process is exciting. Their intellectual curiosity is more energizing than panicked. They respect different cultures rather than fear them. They marvel at the abilities of their fellow humans.

Douthat makes excellent observations but does not address the unique issues we face when compared to past declining civilizations. First, our decadence is fueled by commercial self -interest and enabled by a hitherto unimaginably subtle but intrusive media. It started with 'you are worth it" ads and now permeates every aspect of our lives through social media, infomercials, and advice on how we can stay young and have "fun".Second, the quest for youth has had uniquely damaging effects on parenting and lifestyle choices as idiocies like "age is just a number" take hold. Aspiring to feel or look young is conflated with infantilism seen in the need for instant gratification, entitlement, and blame without accountability. Finally, the ultimate decadence, the mantra about pursuing one's passions in life without regard to whether these are supported by talent or have the potential to lead to economic or social independence. It is no coincidence that so many observe stagnation since the 1960s when the US was no longer the "only game in town" and had to compete globally while the culture failed to evolve and adapt to a world where education, knowledge and skills matter more than passion or effort.

I have a number of friends who fit into this group, mostly wonderful people, but their consumption of resources is astounding. The monthly first-class or private travel to far-flung places, staying in accommodations designed with many of the same scarce resources.

Apollo was a geo-political demonstration of national technical superiority -- a several-shot wonder, which promptly vanished with barely a trace into a strange manned space program mired in low Earth orbit. It was spectacle, not sustained progress. The robot program of planetary exploration has achieved far more and continues to build upon its achievements. To mourn Apollo as the half-century ago, unmatched peak of human achievement confuses a Cold War stunt with true progress.

There has been true scientific/engineering progress in the past half century since Apollo. Both pharmaceutical and surgical advances have improved treatment of cancer and heart disease. Subtract suicide, murder, drug and accidental deaths from all nations stats, and we do have the longest life expectancies. Cars are far safer, more energy efficient, and reliable. Despite the naysayers, interpersonal communication at distance as well as accessibility of knowledge have been advanced by computer and cellphone technology.

The reduction in noxious coal emissions didn't just happen. Natural gas production from new fracking technology made gas cheap enough to displace coal in power plants and oil in home/commercial heating.

The big problem is not that birth rates have declined, but that we have not made the advances in economics, finance, and management science to build a stable economy in the absence of population growth. The present is unsustainable with corporate profits rising far faster than GDP.

Basically this entire column is a 21st century restatement of Aldous Huxley's Brave New World (as updated by Neil Postman in his 1985 classic Amusing Ourselves to Death), namely that our world has entered a narcissistic phase, in which self-amusement, entertainment and the narcotic effect of our media have stifled our individuality, imagination and our creative urges.

In the early 20th century, the great social philosopher John Dewey warned of the coming social crisis that would occur if scientific and technological research and development were not guided by a public and democratic purpose.

In such a case, he said, control of the  technological development would revert by default to the business interests that financed the developments, to the detriment of the general society. Of course, this is exactly what has happened in the 21st century, as described in Mr. Douthat's examples.

Many of the great technological developments of the 20th century that benefited the general public were originally funded by government and academic research, which reflected the public interest. That world is now largely gone, to our great detriment. We are now paying the price.

"50 years removed from the peak of human accomplishment?"
What? These words remind me of that patent office that said back in 1899, that it should close its doors because there was nothing else to be invented.

This assessment strikes me as misplaced. It assumes so many things I disagree with.

We’re stagnating because of deliberate economic choices to maintain a certain standard of living for the aging generations at the expense of the youthful generations.

This article also assumes a potential longevity to our current state of affairs that is not real. In a few decades major coastal cities will be under water. The area around Houston, Texas is particularly a cause for concern. We have 1/3 of all American oil refineries there and 1/2 of all chemical production, but climate models show those facilities could easily be flooded and destroyed by a hurricane induced storm surge. That would decimate our economy and the environment in a way we would not recover from for well over a century. The author points to decadence, but really its intransigence. We could be building infrastructure to protect against that scenario, but instead the wealthy elder generations have bought the fealty of our public servants and obstructed the progress necessary to fuel youthful generations’ development. What climate change? The elders’ oil money beats our fears that may actualize shortly after the elders’ deaths.

This article reflects older generations’ deliberate acceptance of cynical fatalism. I reject it entirely. We need to change, and fast, because the jaded elders are dragging the youth toward death, trying to take us with you like a Pharaoh might take his prized possessions to the crypt. I say no.

Coming up for air after nearly drowning in this tsunami of examples, quotes, stories, digressions, irrelevancies and smugness, one word is missing: money. Money is at the heart of every narrative and yet, motivation is evaded no matter how crazy the pipe dream. 
Politics, careers, education, the arts, sports and entertainment are all subservient to profit; money has slowly used each of these traditions which historically were magnets for excellence into places to swoop in and  exploit with money making schemes. Yes money is power and it breeds decadence and we are floundering!

What Mr. Douthat is describing is “acedia”— a lethargy that come from a spiritual unraveling. What interesting is how much of our social discourse is shaded by an apocalyptic vision of the future: climate change, mega-viral epidemics, random mass shootings, political upheaval and the looming fear of another global economic disaster. All this reflects a lost of faith, in God, our country and in ourselves. There is no self evident truth, our democracy is not the beacon of liberty and hope in the world and our human nature has lost its potency and we imagine transhumanistic descendants taking over our place in history’s evolutionary ascent. 

The next Renaissance will be spiritual not material. If we are to recover from our entropic disillusion, we need to reconnect with God and let his grace and presences restore our compassion for ourselves and for others, our imagination to fine solutions and our will to act.

Sure the big discoveries in transportation and infrastructure have mostly already occurred and what we see now are incremental refinements around the edges. Ditto for medical breakthroughs (although that is still debatable, given the promises of truly personalized medicine). 

In the early days of the gold rush, a prospector could walk into a stream and pick up fist-sized nuggets of alluvial gold - Eureka! A hundred years later, gold mining required huge amounts of capital to deploy gigantic equipment needed to extract fractions of an ounce of gold from the ton of rock that contained it. The alluvial era was a long gone fantasy one only could read and dream about. 

So, too, goeth our Industrial Age, and to some extent our post-industrial, Information Age. Just as in gold mining, there is a pause when the cost to extract what little is there left is greater than the profitability of doing so. This is where we find ourselves now, in a pregnant innovation pause. A time when we are absorbing all that has been introduced thus far, as we evolve toward the next major breakthrough that will unleash a new, innovation-rich epoch that will dramatically change the world one more time. I choose to be hopeful.

"Growth" is what got us global warming and the population spike. The "vitality" of the late 19th to mid 20th century has left us with a polluted, overcrowded world in which some people can barely breathe (Ross totally ignores the developing world in this essay), our food is less nutritious yet more fattening, thousands of species have died, and our bodies are filling up with plastic particles and hormone disruptors, perhaps contributing the epidemics of autism and mental illness. People have retreated to the internet because they aren't able to assemble in meaningful real-life groups for change anymore; the country is too large. "Stagnation" is hardly our biggest problem. And by the way, old people are still capable of being creative.

Every age of popular unrest looks like decadence to privileged elites, especially to intellectual ones, when they have lost their handle on the ideological means to sway the great masses of ordinary people to embrace the fundamentally unjust order of things with enthusiasm and hope, if not for this world then for the next, be that the generational future or some fantasy afterlife. It is their own sense of powerlessness and malaise and lack of imagination they are describing, not some shape of history.

"A time to be born and a time to die...and for every purpose under heaven."

The pie no longer is growing, just the size of the slices are changing - the pie's distribution.

As Mr. Douthat acknowledges, there is little that is new but a lot that is recycled. Movies do not necessarily reflect our times; however, cinema, as a genre, does. We see the rise and fall of disaster movies; then we have the environmental disaster genre, and recently, we've had the Super-Hero genre with the rise of Marvel and DC. Our GDP has remained at around 2% to 3% for the last 20 or so years; in the period leading up to this, we experienced growth rates from 4% to as high as 15% - 19% (admittedly, during WWII), floating around 5% - 8%.

In short, we are not in a state of decadence, we are simply entering steady-state that suggests we're in it for the long haul. What is disconcerting, however, is how the pie is being sliced - the 1% are getting most of it.

The recent decades have seen a huge squandering of resources on Middle Eastern Wars.  We have seen a stagnation of government funding of infrastructure and research, while our chief competitor China has been building infrastructure at a huge rate and now spends far more on scientific research than we do. The super rich pay very low taxes and have gradually accumulated vast wealth, while the middle class has declined. This is what happens when Republicans rule supported by the Citizens United ruling and the Fox and Sinclair propaganda networks.  The electoral college and the Senate ensures minority rule for the foreseeable future. We are doomed.

Decadence in our economic engine is a foreseeable consequence of counterproductive intellectual property laws. Congress long granted (socialistic) monopolies to people that write stories to encourage human expression. In the late 1980’s, at the dawn of the digital age, both the courts and Congress decided that compilations and software engineering needed the same kind of protection given to poetry. 

The U.S. spent the next 30 years forcing nations around the world to accept its expanded vision of monopoly capitalism. The model lets venture capitalists pool their resources and uses government and judicial power to discourage competition. Until recently, it has been good for large U.S. businesses that can replicate a digital backbone and gain exclusive rights around the country and in most parts of the world. The rapid economic expansion of China and the ability of Russia to remain an international force on a shoestring budget comes from their thumbing their nose at the U.S. led restrictions on idea sharing (a/k/a stealing).

The development of civilization has always depended upon the free sharing of ideas and the ingenuity of anyone smart enough to put them to good use. The decadence springs from the unnecessarily long 14-year patents and 100-year copyrights that stifle competition, expand the wealth gap, and encourage billionaires run the world.

We need a system that encourages digital sharing at nominal cost to spark the minds and hearts of young entrepreneurs.

Stop and compare any aspect of life in the US then and now, and not just things that might seem decadently frivolous.  Medicine and health care has probably changed as much in the past 50 years as in any period before, in the science, technology, delivery, and outcomes.  We are in the midst of a revolution in energy production, distribution, and delivery.  Food production continues to innovate and improve, from the mega scale to the boutique heirloom level.  Manufacturing looks nothing like it did 20 years ago, let alone 50, and produces better stuff at lower cost--and still employs millions of people.

Why are our perceptions so misaligned, especially in the chattering classes?  Maybe because too many Americans are disconnected from that physical achievement.  How many people are not scientists, engineers, medical professionals, farmers, technicians, etc.?  And even among these, how many have decades of experience that let them appreciate change?  Finally, how many of us want to see every issue as dire (perhaps reflecting our broad lack of actual understanding and potential skills to address challenges).
