We started our careers believing that we would make a difference, and we did.

I see less of that passion for discovery in younger employees-it is more a job than a career. Management is more concerned with schedules and budgets than innovation that costs money and may not pan out. Quarterly expectation of increased profits drives out risk taking and innovation. Technologies that make our society function, minerals, metals, manufacturing, etc. are undervalued and not "sexy" careers for young people. Instead, the latest app, phone, or game substitutes to a need to satisfy natural curiosity and desire to learn & contribute (e.g., "My contribution to society today is 130 Tweets. What's yours today?") 

We are missing much of the excitement of discovery. Where is the passion? What are we doing wrong? Where is the leadership to inspire today's kids as I was inspired by JFKs challenge to "go to the moon by the end of the decade"? Why are out "leaders" naysayers about science?

Some great points on stagnation in how we don’t use our intelligence to solve problems that don’t need immediate solving like new and improved cell phones and networks. I agree indoor plumbing or antibiotics have achieved more than a lap top in every home and a cell phone in every pocket. When five “tech” companies control 18% of the SP500 wealth, something is wrong with the concentration and particularly direction of our investment and innovation. 

We don’t need self-driving cars and trucks right now on our chaotic overlay of roads, streets and sidewalks.

One possible place to focus our wealth and innovation; build new manufacturing, service and residential footprints. Polycentric patterns of development. 

Build new communities with efficiently-located centers of manufacturing and commerce with fewer people living in  polluted, crowded environments. These are not new concepts.

We already have the land space and methods of transit, automated manufacturing and de-localized electricity production to place centers for integrated development where we want them. Need a vision.

Last year, Forbes magazine cited a study that had 78% of Americans living "paycheck-to-paycheck". While Mr Douthat counsels us not to be discouraged by media portrayal of instability, I find it hard to stomach an argument that we live in an age of unrestrained self-indulgence, when facts-on-the-ground serve as such a ready counter. https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackfriedman/2019/01/11/live-paycheck-to-paycheck-government-shutdown/#43ced33a4f10

Three observations and an alternate suggestion:  First - Douthat's anecdotal revisionism of history isn't proof of anything but a certain ability at wordsmithing to affect meaning.  Second - much of our scientific and social progress over the last 150 years was spurred by government subsidies (direct and indirect).  Examples range from land grants to companies building railroads to tax write offs  Third - too much of our so-called science consists of compiling and regurgitating studies done by others, rather than by original research.  Examples range from land grants to companies building railroads to tax benefits linked to hard research and development.  Suggestion - instead of re-defining history using conjecture ala Alexis de Tocqueville, why not test theories - the one I would suggest is testing whether the Republican tax cuts during the Reagan, W Bush, and Trump years siphoned money into financial schemes benefiting a few individuals rather than stimulating infrastructure and innovation that benefit economic and social development for the many.  We need to build alternatives to 20th century transportation modes and develop real medicines that reach beyond repackaging old drugs into new patents in order to raise prices.

If this were a term paper, I'd give it a C. Throwing the kitchen sink at an argument with fundamental flaws, Douthat overwhelms us with arguments piling on each other that do more to cloud his thesis than illuminate it. Culture is like the water in an aquarium - blaming the fish for dirty aquarium water is pointless. The individual in today's Western society is stuck with a controlling political movement - Conservatism - that resists reality, refuses to adapt, and exists only to make the already wealthy even more wealthy. Like dragons sitting on a pile of gold, conservative capitalism piles up wealth without larger purposes - it's unsustainable. Why should individuals hoard cash (Forbes list of billionaires) while Americans go hungry? Why should we continue to subsidize fossil fuel corporations in today's world of climate change? Why does the DOD budget have to be so large when we can't have health care and education? Why would we pull out of the Paris Agreement, setting ourselves apart from the world community? Looking for decadence? Don't point at the fish, look to those ruling elite who keep the aquarium water dirty. Before lecturing the rest of us on a popular crisis of Decadence, Douthat should take a step back and look objectively at his own core assumptions based in Conservatism and Catholicism - there you will find the roots of Decadence. Pointing at secondary outcomes while ignoring root causes misses the forest for the trees. Great comments, questionable thesis.

Well-written, but disappointingly narrow in scope, given the complaint about the capital-W West. Examples provided are remarkable blips rather than compelling illustrations an era-defining malaise. The author should travel to Western Europe, or anywhere, and see for themselves how diverse outlooks, visions, and indeed problems can be. 

Further, it is frustrating to see my generation’s problems waved away as signs of decadence. A more thoughtful analysis might show interest in markers of mounting inequities, public divestment from collective projects (infrastructure, institutions), or our loss of regulatory power.

Yes it is more difficult to think of things to invent.  The simpler things have been invented.  Now we need more highly educated people to make the breakthroughs that you cannot make tinkering in your garage - where you need a laboratory.  And people with science degrees. But we are in the era, once again, where science is suspect rather than admired (read about Stalin and the geneticists).  The result is that our population is becoming less intelligent and less able to have a passing familiarity with the branches of science.

(Maybe stagnation is from our worse-every-decade silly teaching methodologies. Rather than using iPads we should be using books for K-8.)

And as far as people starting their own businesses, my father started and ran his own little business for 30 years.  But now, for the most part, starting a small business is a pipe dream.  Either there is a big box chain or Amazon to reduce your profit to zero.  Or if it is something more in the sciences, like alternative fuels, there is a giant industrial that does Not want your little invention to see the light of day.

The masses are now opiated; first from television and now the internet. You cannot have the drive and desire to succeed when there is no cultivation or opportunity.

I believe we need to get away from value-laden words like "stagnation" and "decadence" to have any meaningful conversation.

Imagine the growth of a mature Western Oregon forest, or the Amazon Rain Forest.  The "old growth"  form-- which might require 800 or 1000 years to achieve -- looks "stagnant" to a forester or a Bolsenaro or a Trump, but an ecologist will tell you it is a dynamic, living system that is far from "decadent".  

I don't think we are "decadent" as a society.  I think we are physically, morally, and intellectually lazy.  

Complacent, not decadent.
So, decadence.  There could be something of beauty in decadence, including apologies like "decadence avec elegance".  The question is: is there any way to avoid the Dark Ages?

Not a word about the impending climate crisis or how we must forcefully fight global warming.   America needs to build again and there's plenty to build, fix and upgrade and we've got the brains and the brawn to do it, in spades.  A Green New Deal lays it out as a starting point for debate, despite the author trying to equate Trump and Sanders.

In a thoughtful argument that stagnation defines our age, there's not one word about the single greatest threat we face. Striking, isn't it?  Maybe ignoring the climate crisis in an essay about cultural decadence is a clever bit of irony on Douthat's part.

I wonder how human society can adapt to population decline? Decline in numbers we must, for there are so many of us that feeding and transporting and entertaining us is unsustainable. With population decline, GDP growth stops being the way we measure our progress? What can replace it? A￼ large birth rate stops being the way we measure our social strength. What can replace it?

The progress of the nation of Japan is a worthy experiment in a couple of decades of more-or-less gentle population decline. What can the rest of the world learn from their experience?

I agree that our society is decadent. Much of the problem is our focus on materialism - capitalism, socialism, it's all the same - just economics.  While I don't know where or when, but from a historical perspective,  it seems likely  to me that a new religious leader will arise and provide some moral leadership.  Perhaps this is a hope, since I'd rather not  have us turn into a totalitarian state where we are numbed by virtual reality.

Thanks for crystalizing a vague unease I've felt for years. A case in point: my son is a computer scientist who took 6 years off to build a smaller, faster UI engine. No one does this anymore, but he is a stubborn inventor who goes his own way. He got picked up by Y-combinator (the Silicon Valley incubator). But even with that endorsement, he cannot persuade VC's to fund him. They literally said that while his invention is amazing and useful, it is not a platform that can harvest user data. He can see millions being thrown at half-baked retread ideas, but he is bootstrapping his company the old fashioned way. He has been recruited by the big tech companies, but he doesn't believe in their mission, so he has chosen this much tougher, but I think more American, path. I think we need more people like him to bring about real change and new directions, people who are not satisfied with spending their efforts on playing variations on an old theme.

It is amazing to me that this excellent, provocative paper on decadence completely misses its clearest example: the ability of our society to proceed unconcerned through years of increasing evidence - both scientific and visible to anyone who is looking - of the accelerating and existential rate of global environmental destruction! What greater example of "stalemate and stagnation" could there be than to be floating unconcerned in a pot of water steadily heating (literally) towards boiling and to be excessively concerned about the dedadence of our culture?

One of the worst parts of the technology revolution that is the Internet are the companies that are taking personal data that should remain private and monetizing it for their own profits so that other companies can target people in whatever way they want. This is not innovative—it’s simply another way for business to take advantage of people. One simple change could be made to better protect the privacy that everyone gives up simply by using the Internet for something as innocuous as checking today’s weather report. Instead of forcing us to opt in simply by using a site, the default should be opt out, thus forcing companies to obtain our approval for them to sell our most personal data to the highest bidders. 

Mr. Douthat has written an interesting column, but it would have been more useful had he identified some of the government and business policies that have led to our age of decadence. We have politicians who want to make significant changes and move us onto a path of forward progress, like innovations to address climate change, but we have a president and a Republican Party that wants to reduce us to nothing more than arguing over social issues while the rich hoard much of the country’s wealth, the country stagnates, and we lose our place in the race for world competition for innovation and progress.

Ross, I much appreciate your article here, which has such good research and also much food for thought.  I would like to note that it was the literary and artistic "Decadence" era of the 1890's in Europe which became the harbinger of the horrors to come in World War I and beyond.  So today it is the artists and writers who become the true "Vates," as they say in Irish, the seers or visionaries who provide the hints for what is to come.  The contrast you make between virtual reality and actual reality is most valuable in our confusing times.  The images we are bombarded with, the "reality TV" political world we witness, is not by any means the genuine moral and political crisis we face.  The political ideologues and religious fanatics, ever salient, have only brought us wars upon wars throughout history.  The solutions you prescribe here require all citizens to face and to accept the daily complexity, the ambiguities and the paradoxes of our world.  I hope for, but do not yet see, an electorate ready for that.  An education in the liberal arts would be a good start.

This is a compelling argument. It is—to use an overused word—sad. Absent from Douthat’s recitation of stagnation statistics is the rate of US spending on education, which increased dramatically and then stagnated in accord with the innovation and productivity in our society noted here. I would be curious for the author’s impression of this correlation. I propose that a society gets out of its resources what it invests.

Indeed, when society pushed to land a man on the moon, no one had the entertaining web and social media to distract them from that inspiring and 24/7 goal. And, who actually “makes” things anymore? Looks like we could use a healthy dose of retro-ism in how we think and live.

There are a lot of words in this essay. But there's one word  missing.

The word is "climate." Search the text. It's not there.

It's absence is peculiar for two reasons. First, if you accept Ross's thesis, the climate crisis has to be right up there among the challenges our "decadent" civilization is not facing. 

Second, if there's a challenge that can shake us out of our moral and spiritual torpor, the climate crisis is it.

We don't need another world war to wake us from our slumbers. We don't need to fly to Mars to rediscover virtue. We just need to face this existential challenge that's staring us in the face. If the nations of the West can't do that, then maybe we deserve to go the way of the Roman Empire. 

What I think is more likely, though, is that we will -- eventually -- confront it. And when we do, we will discover that the only workable solution is to build a civilization that's wise, just, and sustainable. Not necessarily the "Green New Deal," but something in that spirit.

That effort is going to change everything. And it's not going to take 400 years. We don't have that much time. 

So, if it feels like the end of an era, that's because it is. We either build a wise, just, and sustainable civilization or we fall. 

Either way, this era of "decadence" will soon be over.

The Romans fell and there were others, so-called Barbarians, to move in and set up shop--and so the churl of human development continued. What this writer fails to address is our place, as a species, over the long haul. We've gone from a hunter-gatherer to agrarian to urban species and now there are too many of us. How we quell the rising tide of humans is the question, and so far we barely acknowledge this is an issue. The US may have a negative birthrate, but our problems are global and there are hordes of urbanites gobbling up the earth's resources. Global warming isn't an abstraction; we cannot survive without birds and bees. We barely comprehend the complexity of the ecology in which we live. We need water, food and air more than gods, gadgets, or ideas.

I think Ross has grasped the word decadence as an "aha!" description for his collection of observations. Like the story of the blind men each grasping a different part of an elephant and reaching different conclusions (a snake, a rope, a tree trunk), Ross's conclusion is based on conforming to a previously experienced or known model. 
I prefer to believe that the phenomena of global climate change, bio and tech revolutions, and an aging population signal a necessary evolution  (or revolution) toward a no-growth economic model that will challenge creativity in all arenas.

I, for one, haven't gotten used to the absurdities of our governing party.  Unfortunately, many seem to have gotten used to it.  That doesn't mean I am pessimistic.  I've lived long enough and have seen enough history to know movements come and go and I'm not sure our current reality is even a movement.  One of the major problems contributing to today's disappointments is that people expect instant gratification.  If you are sick, there is a pill for it. If you own stocks, you expect instant dividends (No, no, no, don't put money back into development!). If you are working on a computer, it is too slow (forgetting that it is hundreds of time faster than it used to be). Another major problem is that people who haven't lived the history haven't learned enough about it. Most of today's population have no real idea about people trying to scale the Berlin Wall to escape communism or about the USSR's extreme measures to put down the protests in Hungary.  I saw it on live TV.  I agree with much of what you say about our perceived views of college campuses and individuals who believe internet conspiracy theories.  They are a very small percentage of the population but they get outsized publicity because they are a "man bites dog" story. Our institutions might be flawed but are the only things keeping our world together.  We need to take a deep breath and work to fulfill the promises of our institutions.

Well written and accurate as a diagnosis, but as a prescription, I think you have the wrong model in mind. We’re witnessing a repeating upheaval with a period of 50-60 years. The Russian economist Nicolas Kondratiev and the American Joseph Schumpeter (and others) recognized this period and Schumpeter gave it the name, K-wave after Kondratiev. We are at the end of a cycle just as we were in 1969 and just as we were in the early 19th century when the Know-Nothing Party rose and the Whigs disappeared, at the end of the first Industrial Revolution. A new K-wave wipes the slate clean. In 1969 practical and affordable computers were almost a reality and the wave that started in the early 1970s carried us to today. That wave is toast. The new wave forming is plainly visible and it involves sustainability in all its forms including renewable energy and carbon absorption. The new wave is being resisted big time by the entrenched energy interests and the politicians who enable them. The political challenge for this generation is to throw off the yoke of the existing paradigm.

Fire can be seen as a technology. As such it can burn your hand or cook your meal or both, but the technology is not to blame, the blame or praise is in how we use technology. So what is this computer revolution? Yes it is new technology. But more importantly, it is a function of a new theory of mind, that is computational and representational. So the computer revolution is at base a cognitive revolution, which sees the mind, not as a fallen creature needing to be controlled by an elite class of thinkers, but as an individual mind that can access a collective  mind that will enhance the individual mind.  You can google anything at any time and greatly expand your know how and know what. That is of course about increased intelligence, not necessarily greater wisdom. This is the real problem; we have a new fire that we do not yet know how to cope with, and we fear that it is uncontrollable and will burn us to the ground. And there will be no elite class, (the priests that absolved us our our sins) that will emerge with a wisdom that will guide this new intelligence. They who have found this new intelligence will have to find the wisdom to guide it. With this new theory of mind, that is computational, binary, and representational, we all will have to find our way; but not by blaming the fire when it burns your hand, and praising  it as it cooks your meal.

This essay is built off Mr. Douthat’s personal list of social/cultural grievances. Fine. However no mention of the fundamental change in American work since the 1970’s is a major flaw in this thesis, especially considering his issues with vaporware foisted by our tech economy. Everything that characterizes the new decadence comes after a major structural shift wherein the things we made are no longer made here and those who made them were forgotten by our community. Those things that are still made here are more expensive and lower quality than those made elsewhere and those Americans that continue to make have less security, promise of advancement, and live in areas more rife with crime. And debt. Those of us not in the top percent of earners are ensnared by debts. We currently collectively owe $14 trillion dollars and live under a system that makes every macro-economic effort to ensure that our debts are not inflated away. We are like fish in a great net. 

Here’s my grievance: I would propose that we’ve been sold a lie about from where our salvation will come. We need to remember that it’s what we make and how we make it that defines us. The enabling lie that life should be easier needs to be put down and we need to not rest on laurels. We need to learn that we are not truly free unless we as a people can make decisions that allow us to be.

I can't fix climate change or Donald Trump. All I can do is make my little patch of Earth better. I plant native plants to help bees and birds and butterflies. I recycle and avoid as much plastic as I can. I volunteer in my son's school, in youth athletics, and in our local parks system.

Ross is right-we exist in decadence. We exist in a place where people think arguing with others on Twitter on Facebook is a valid use of time. It isn't. We mistake outrage on internet for action. We live in echo chambers of purity. None of these things equals actual positive change, or forward momentum. Twitter and Facebook are the internet version of the petition. It offers an illusion of progress without any real effort.

And every minute we spend fighting other people behind their computers is one less minute we spend being better people.

I love having the knowledge of the world at my fingertips. But I will not use that knowledge to prove how right I am, how virtuous I am. Instead, I am using it to prove to myself that I can make positive impacts where I live. I don't need to harangue people on the internet to plant flowers and volunteer. I just need to go do it.

The USA has become as regimented, regulated, bureaucratized as the old time Soviet Union.
As the cynical saying goes.......
"We have met the enemy......and he is us."
Why does it require a Masters Degree to monitor kindergartners?
Why does it require an MBA to become an "entrepeneur"?
Do we really need Offshore Banking at all?
Why are we NOT taxing the Internet?
Why are Blueberries shipped from Chile, bypassing the local farms on the way to my supermarket?

All this and nary a word about Capitalism which is the driving force of decadence. Instead we get symptoms rather than an analysis of the “free market” dynamics and conservative ideology behind this itemized list.
I disagree.Extreme Individualism is  here to blame. Empire of developed individualism goes to decadence.

The most depressing thing about the West, any modern society, becoming decadent in the 21st century?

I would have to say it's how a society becomes a lock in, containment system no matter how open, free, in fact open to immigrants it declares itself to be. By lock in, containment system I mean a system which coopts every idea, every attempt to break out of system, and turns it into a measure making further breakout in every way impossible.

A good example of this is the Catch Me If You Can film about Frank Abagnale: He breaks out of system but then is used to reinforce system. It particularly depresses me what language is becoming in the 21st century: It's not so much to enlighten but to advertise, insidiously persuade, become a mesh/barrage/impenetrable barrier of legal/business jargon, and anyone who thinks and writes clearly appears to be coopted to do the reverse to point of even writing cryptic sentences, as if the eventual project by power is not so much to make people illiterate but develop a language the majority of people cannot decipher.

It's all about surveillance, codes, ciphers, complex mathematics, propaganda, correct speech, complex and confusing procedures to make virtually everything as impenetrable as possible. Do not take your automobile, computer apart, someone will fix it for you. Authorities behind everything, every step you take watched, your life designed like a video game by the no doubt increasing Video Game Design Experts of our Existence.

"hey look at that over there" An attempt to , in a self perceived witty college essay style, dismiss the concerns of a society in need of change. Yes the constant ,misinformation skews reality but to suggest that it's all just in our minds and we are creating a false narrative is a misread. A move away from absolute materialism would not be a bad thing.  Issues you refer to; drug addictions, the anxiety, etc are a direct result of a society obsessed with "ACQUIRING STUFF". The "outrageous socialism" that the US media, on both sides of the aisles, constantly scorn in reference to Bernie, exists in thriving societies all over the world. In Canada we have Universal Single Payer health care, we have 6 months paid leave both maternity and paternity, we have not free yet but low cost Post Secondary with enough programmes in place to make it nearly debt free if a student adjusts spending while attending. We also have a $12 min wage and our daycare and pre-school workers make $17plus per hour ensuring we stand a chance to keep well suited people in one of the most important vocations. Our teachers & Social Workers start in the 55-70 thousand range because we do not lace the burden of education on the municipalities, many of which are unable to afford more than mid twenty thousand for young teachers.etc. We have many socialist policies but we are not Russia, Cuba or Venezuela as the media likes to allude all socialism is. The issue in those countries was CORRUPTION not Socialism

This is a remarkable diagnosis of our time, bringing into focus some reflections I've been having of late. 

One thing in particular stands out "true dystopias are distinguished, in part, by the fact that many people inside them don’t realize that they’re living in one." This is, almost word-for-word, something I've found myself saying, in the last few months.

I said it out loud, once, and the person I was talking with replied with reassurances that it couldn't possibly be true that we've slid into a true dystopia, because we're all so affluent and comfortable by all objective measures. 

Well, I did not reply, the residents of Huxley's Brave New World were affluent and comfortable; all they had to give up was their humanity. 

I think - or hope - that Mr. Douthat is correct, and we are not yet in a full-blown dystopia. The quotation from Auden may be closer to the mark: we are now living "without creativity, warmth, or hope."

Don’t we wish it was decadent? Instead we live in a world of bland sameness. The internet and the end of the natural world have made us like a giant ant heap everywhere. Everybody is on the net and thinks they’re important but in reality, nobody is important. In a world of 7.8 billion how can anyone or anything be special or unusual? Clinton, W, Obama, trump, we think it’s all so unique and meaningful but in reality none of it has mattered. Things stumble along in their boring sameness and we think it’s so important but it’s all white bread now. In a few years we’ll look back and wonder what the fuss was all about. Too bad. We could use something to get excited about.

Indeed, decadent we are and led by the good ole USA. We are paranoid, led by the recognition that other countries and areas of the world are catching up with us and thus all the power we had is slowly being distributed to many parts of the world. We liked being King of the world and we were a benevolent ruler. It is becoming abundantly clear that the world is drifting into a time when there will be several co-equal kingdoms and we are having a rough time accepting that fact.

There is an old saying, “be careful what you ask for, you might get it”. Well, here we are. As we awaken to this fact, we in the United States have become paranoid with many not wanting to share our throne. Trump masterfully used this paranoia to get elected, while many of our allies are refusing to kowtow to his aspirations.

Per the opinion, “A society run by the cruel and arrogant might not be decadent; a society where even the wise and good can’t legislate might be.”

It seems that this is where we as a nation are. We have lost our way and with it our influence in the world. When was the last time a European leader visited the United States or invited Trump to visit their country? If we want to continue to lead the free world they must want to follow. 

Friends Matter, and we are losing ours.

I like reading essays that tackle "the big picture, and I read this essay with great eagerness. 

Mr. Douthat stretches the meaning of decadence far beyond its association with wealthy and cultured classes falling away from the obligations and duties that come with their economic and cultural privileges. It makes no sense to call laborers and peasants, even when they are shovel-leaners, decadent; all they're doing is trying to survive. The only people who can be called decadent, and who are responsible for a decadent age, are the wealthy.

Liberals may be faulted for at times touting impossible ideals, but Conservatives (almost by definition) are at fault for eternally going to the past to find their standards for society. Babies are fine, but with a planet bursting to the seams with homo sapiens, we do not need to encourage having babies. What we desperately need is a new economic model based on recyclin, not growth, based on ecology, not exploitation, based on respect for Nature, not technology. 

In sum, Mr. Douthat shows a complete lack of imagination when it comes to ideas about what's good for the future.

What interests me about Ross' analysis here, as well as, more generally, his post-Trump politics (and much the same could be said for Brooks and Stephens) is the creeping realization that theory and practice are often strange bedfellows.  For the longest time, conservatives like Douthat put their faith in the Republican party because its rhetoric championed those ideas that conservative intellectuals believed in.  They held their noses at the excess, the phony religiosity, the hypocritical deficit spending, the unmistakable signs of racial intolerance, etc., etc., because they were convinced that the missteps were just bumps along the road to conservative utopia.  Perhaps they can be forgiven their naivté, but it's high time they copped to it.  The sad fact is that the theory espoused by the Republicans since Goldwater at least, was always, at best, an illusion.  Trump hasn't changed the Republican party.  He has merely exposed it for what it always was: a reactionary con.

All this time I’ve been reading these columns and disagreeing with the vast majority of them. It turns out that Ross is just much more suited to long form texts! Thank you for putting this out there, I am looking forward to reading the book.

antiques and objects of cultural significance have been desired and collected unabatedly for more than two thousand years- until now. as a dealer, i see no interest in people under 50 for any antiques or cultural artifacts. young customers like "design" but independent of time, place, culture.
popular tv show: downton abbey, in which we see extreme attachment and enforcement of cultural norms, etiquette, rule, ritual. so, ant-decadence.

I am almost always inclined to disagree with Douthat. However, I am intrigued by his assessment of the Internet wunderkinds. What has Amazon truly given us? More and more-quickly delivered junk and entertainment to stupidly us. Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram? Isolation sold as connection and ignorance sold as valuable information. Google? Disinformation at your fingertips to befuddle and bedazzle. Very little of the tech revolution is advancing our lot as beings living in a natural world. 

Focusing on what is genuine and close, shutting down the screen can help us return to creativity and growth as social and intellectual beings. 

An old soldier I knew once told me that peace is death. I disagreed with him at the time because I was so immersed in the swirling energy of youth. Now I see what he meant all too clearly.

I agree there is stagnation or “decadence” as Ross  calls it. What is new under the sun? Nothing. A faster lap top, a newer phone, better smartwatch, all which all do the same thing. Space technology? Nothing new. Space X and related space companies all relying on the same rocketry technology available for the past 60 years. All we have is recycling of the same ideas.

Are we in a boredom crisis?  I am reminded of retirees at a condo complex. They have nothing to do but sit at home and watch their neighbors and brood over violations of the condo rules. The more they watch their neighbors and brood over the rules the angrier they get. Nothing to do, but get angry.

Add to that an impending climate and environmental crisis and we get paralyzed in fear. Boredom and fear seems like a contradiction in terms, but is it. All these crises  seem so far off to many, but so near.

The answer. Just sit in your living room and get angry.

Oh, please.  If you want to get to the political roots of decadence, look not to the “technocratic” management of Obama, but the utter bad faith, hypocrisy, and obstructionism of the conservative right in American politics. We’re still waiting for any significant public investment in infrastructure, which Obama first proposed as a response to the Great Recession.  Declining innovation is due to the increasing concentration of the American economy and the power of large corporations to stymie innovation through lobbying to close off competition and aggressive uses of copyright and patent law, developments abetted and cheered by the right in American politics. It’s conservatives, not liberals, who for the past generation have systematically defunded basic science and health research, along with American higher education, the foundations of innovation.  The blind fetishization of markets, without any inkling that competitive markets actually require a strong and capable government if they are not to decay into rent-seeking oligopoly, is a particularly pernicious conservative shibboleth. Ross, notwithstanding the predictable reactions of the NY Times readership, I commend you for the effort in writing this thought-provoking piece. In fact, a new president might move us in a better direction but it will not begin to solve the problems created by our decadence without a wholesale shift in the perspective of the American people. Unfortunately, we lost the best opportunity to foster this shift in 2008 when Bush and Obama decided to bailout the banks for their malfeasance. This decision fostered the decadence that you describe and prevented the American people from experiencing the pain of unregulated capitalism. There is certain to be another opportunity and it may be impossible at that time to prevent the pain. Of course, if we had real policymakers in office we'd have honest debates about the issues that have caused the decadence and the political leaders would permit votes on important legislation. But since decadence permeates our three branches of government it  is likely that their stagnation will continue until a catastrophe strikes.

Perhaps also, you are looking more at what happens when one generation is demographically so dominant that their natural cycle of aging is seen as the standard of the entire culture.

After the Depression and WWII, with historical low birth rates in the US and Europe, we witnessed the "Boomer" surge.

We "Depression Babies" watched as our society was defined by them: Youthful (rebellious, exploring) Middle Aged (material growth, development of youthful ideas) and now entering Old Age (cautious, not ready to invest in new things, fearful of tomorrow). 

Those in the generations after the Boomers will suffer for another decade or so until the Boomers move on into history.

Ross Douthat's definition of decadence is alive and well in medicine in three ways. First, we have a system overwhelmed with the the end effects of gluttony: morbid obesity, type 2 diabetes, hypertension, vascular disease, obstructive sleep apnea, and osteoarthritis. These are chronic diseases of a society that just doesn't care about health responsibility on an individual level. Second, that same medical system throws endless amounts of money at these same problems in an inefficient and greed-driven way. Where else in the world does everyone get a CT scan for abdominal pain in the ER? Where else are joint replacements a virtual walk-in service? Our individual ability to push our own poor health choices' costs onto society at large is a tragedy of the commons and decadence at its worst. Third, medical cures are limited by biology and chemistry. There are only so many receptors for drugs and so many surgical approaches for disease. There are real limitations to cures, despite the pie-in-the-sky hope for genetic and micro-robotic treatments for everyone. Chemistry and shear cost will forever prohibit the use of esoteric treatments in the general population. Thus, there is an asymptotic limit to any treatment's success rate. Breast cancer is a perfect example.  More women are diagnosed with mammograms, ultrasounds, and MRIs, but guess what? Mortality rate hasn't budged. Decadence indeed, no matter how many trillions of dollars we spend on "healthcare" in this country.

Mr. Douthat cites a report that marks 1980 as the beginning of the decline in business investment, without acknowledging that year as the beginning of the Reagan revolution. Instead, we got declining investment, increasingly concentrated wealth and the stagnation that now so troubles Mr. Douthat. We have continued on the same path--over and over again--with no political or economic vision except tax cuts and deregulation, which only exacerbates the social decay and decadence. But Mr. Douthat just skips over the most significant political--and, cultural--event that created our current state. It was the election of Ronald Reagan. Since Reagan--the original "make America great again" guy--we are locked into a present that looks to replay the past rather than face the changes and challenges of the future. "Trump Digs Coal" is a fit symbol of turning our backs on the future to resurrect the past. It is a meaningless slogan, that does nothing for those who dutifully cheer for it, but it is nonetheless a cultural wedge that divides our nation and is used politically to prevent any action on a wide range of economic and environmental issues. We are immobilized, unable to take action that will give us a future, and at the same time applauding those who brought us to this point--that is decadence.

If we directed these fruits to people who spend rather than invest them, the spending would create real opportunities for NBTs to arise rather than the hype we get now.  

Meanwhile, we live on a very large spaceship whose water and heat control mechanisms and biological diversity are changing because of our numbers and desires; these changes are immune to public relations and exist whether or not we see or like them.  We dream of the days where growth and dynamism are possible, before these limits existed or we were aware of them.  And we summon our best public relations to make the limits vanish.  This is true decadence.  It is continuing our high stakes poker game to win pots that are crumbling in the heat.

When people can make easy money from investing in a myriad of formulas that have been created by a handful of resourceful egghead economists and physicists, then yes, people are going to choose the easy way to "success". 

When people can make money from something like modern opioids, (a mutated travesty that was once properly used to treat extreme pain), yes, they will invest in that also, even though it contributes to horrific low productivity across the country. 

I think that the old gangster credo that "I do this for my family" has trickled into the psyche of the average businessperson--and conscience is barely given a second thought, as the need to have their kids go to the best schools take precedence over anything else.

Couple all this with the mind numbing 24/7 and instant gratification of the internet, and we are left with some youth who cannot even remember a phone number by heart, let alone invent a phone.

It's all too easy, so it's all becoming too hard. And we are so busy destroying the planet, we don't even care that we are destroying the obstacles meant to protect it too. 

Don't you think that the youth like Sanders and Warren because of possible renewal from this decadence? It looks like Mr. Douthat has made the perfect argument for their presidency.

This article has a lot of interesting ideas.  However,  I wish that it explored more fully to what extent many of the negative trends it describes, e.g., declines in the establishment of new businesses and new scientific discoveries, are attributable to decadence as opposed to other factors.  To me, it seems that term 'decadence' typically implies a significant ethical or moral failing or weakness.  It is reasonable to argue that the negative trends described by the article do reflect some kind of ethical or moral decline in American society.  However, some of these trends could also be products of quite different causes.  For example, the declining numbers of new businesses could reflect a more difficult business environment than that seen in the 1970's.  The current power of online and national chain retailers might well make it much harder for a would-be entrepreneur to establish a new retail store than it was in the 1970's.  Similarly, there might be inherent scientific or technological barriers that limit the development of new innovations with the transformative power of the automobile or the airplane.  I don't dismiss the argument that a moral or spiritual decline may partially explain the issues discussed by Mr. Douthat.  However, I think that the article would be stronger if it also considered alternative explanations for the same trends, even if it rejected these explanations in the end.

A very thoughtful piece. Cultural criticism/intellectual history for the layperson. Kudos to NYT for providing the space for such serious minded pieces.  

One quibble.  If Obama fiddled with mediocre things, it was due in no small part to the united and incessant obstructionism of the GOP.  His proposed infrastructure spending in response to the financial crisis was reduced by some 75 or 80 percent by GOP obstructionists.  Any big ideas regarding green technologies were routinely ridiculed as pie in the sky; while Michelle Obama's modest pietistic campaign of better eating was met with a near hysterical opposition.

Reactionary politics, abetted by the right wing media, has been a positively harmful reality since Reagan.

Amy Klobuchar is a refreshing antidote. Much of the ennui Douthat sees is the feigned cynicism of reactionaries who would rather stand on their grandmother's chest than pay taxes toward the common good.

Like others, I am amazed that this long, thoughtful piece does not mention climate change.  Almost every indicator and forecast is pointing towards a time, arriving in about one to five decades, when our decadent society will be confronted by the raw necessity of survival, as vast and grim new realities rise up and thrust themselves in our faces.  That can be avoided, but only by an effective revolution that transforms our economies into more egalitarian, participatory, low-to-no-growth societies, ones where we embrace new energy technologies and more earthy, less greedy existences.  So, I think the first few paragraphs are absolutely terrific, but I think Mr. Douthat's crystal ball functions very poorly after that point.

I really liked this article, but agree with other comments that it's pretty astounding that there's no section here on the climate emergency and how it might liven things up a bit in this age of decadence.

Maybe a grinning DJT tossing rolls of paper towels to a crowd in Puerto Rico will be the lasting image of These Times.  Although Iowa is admittedly hard to beat.

An awesome and delightful essay.  By definition, not everything that one writes can be one's best work, but I wish that Douthat's average columns approached the insight and perspicacity of this longer piece.
My community, given over 40 years of working on it, can’t bring a train with 1970s technology to the train station (already built).  We all want it, but cannot have it.  That is America today.

"Decadence" is a curious way to describe a society that knows what it needs to do--and refuses to do so. 

We have a political party that is essentially implementing a societal death plan based on lies. The alleged goal is to allow a few people to play with money in a contest to see who has the biggest pile. 

Curiously, a key provider of the financial means, tactics and goals are a few consulting companies, among them Bain (Romney) and Mackenzie (Buttigieg), who turn out what are allegedly our most dynamic, incorrupt politicians. Yet they are using the skills and knowledge provided by the most corrupting element of our society: financial fantasy games. 

For centuries we had little actual knowledge and had to rely on speculation. Today, we have a knowledge base that can identify and address crucial societal and physical problems and address them effectively. To the extent we use this knowledge base at all, it seems to be more often to efficiently mislead. Ross is himself a misled victim when he treats planned population decline by having fewer children as a problem rather than a success story. 

Is what we are seeing today decadence or dispair?

A lot of us keep slogging on, inventing things, getting patents, starting companies, taking personal risks, failing and failing, and, sometimes, succeeding.  Making real things out of real atoms and not being overly seduced by the virtual.  The problem is that a complacent society is risk averse and comfortable in its stagnation.  For example, the very idea that new technologies invented to counteract global warming are an economic threat is ludicrous.  This stuff is great for the economy.  Producing new wealth from which everyone benefits demands that people know how to deal with risk and the fear it engenders.  A healthy society needs risk takers, and it should encourage and support them.  It's all about managing risk, not avoiding it.

A great and important article.

In short, in brief, we need to look at the basics of what it is to be a human in the short time we are in this reality.

We need be extremely concrete and practical, yes, BUT, at the same time use time to consider what happens after death for life. I mean to understand today and tomorrow, one needs to invest more than we on average do on what our next life might be so we better know what this life should be. 

If we live to an average of say 80, it is far too short to make the mistake on not considering what it is all about. 

Yes, the baby boomers, say, made many mistakes, but no one is listening as to what those mistakes came from and that is one of our biggest mistakes.

I have found the internet on the computer computer and smart phone to be the worst distractions fo my creative production. In the visual arts, students always refer to movies or video games. I keep telling them to stop being passive, that their imagination is just as good if they let themselves have the empty space to imagine. 

In 3D design, it was very hard to get them to imagine themselves in space, to see from different perspectives. The best thing I read in a design book is that everything 2D is an illusion. Even artist friends I told this argued the fact. Start thinking of life in 3D and it expands your mind and ability to imagine.

The most proximate cause of decadence that I see is not technology but people willing to follow an ignorant demagogue. That is the really scary thing, especially when humans are facing an imminent existential threat in climate change.

It's odd that the author does not discuss  why decadence is not found in the  incapacity of most (all?)  technologically advanced states to decide to address it head on with all due diligence and vigor. 

Yes there are itsy bitsy steps to mitigate warming gases, but
these pale badly with the status quo behavior we see
in Japan, Australia, Brazil, this country... that aim to increase
coal and oil production, and justify doing so  in terms of  greater national economic growth, good jobs, the usual litany of reassuring bromides that convey the good life.

The vast majority of the investor class continues with business as usual in deciding that carbon assets are still
to be invested in for the eventual profit to be made upon
their exploitation. The market continues to reward such
investment decisions. Dividends and asset values 
are paid out and recomputed to reward this conception of what we need to do to maintain the good life. 

There is some good talk of late that this might be changing, but there is only very little,  not yet much, good evidence of that. 

What does one call the insistence upon continuing self destructive behavior, indeed collective suicidal behavior,
simply because the necessarily disruptive effort to change  is just  too great even to imagine it?

I would call that a very good example of decadence. 

So I am puzzled why the author does not also.

This is a brilliant piece.  The world of capitalist modernism may be slowly ending, in a quiet way.  Douthat is our Catholic version of Georg Lukacs, our conservative version of Wolfgang Streeck.  Is there anything that comes to teh rescue, or is will it be just a whimper?

Mr. Douthat argues we face decadence, not a true crisis. But he completely neglects climate change. Decadent or not, our society is already facing an existential threat; it's hard to see how we can retain a "comfortably numb" life. Just ask  the climate refugees of Australia and California if their problems are merely in the virtual world.

I saw that decadence come into the University of Michigan in the late 1970s as the early Generation Xers (those born between 1960-1968) began to show up.  They were much more materialistic, conventional, brutal, nihilistic, and intolerant than their predecessors.  These were people without ideals, but bent on securing whatever they could for themselves and their friends.  Their predecessors were a seasoned but amiable lot and this was the atmosphere of the college at the time.

Fast forward to now:  We see them increasingly taking charge in corporate America and academia.  The likes of Sean Hannity, Laura Ingraham, Paul Ryan, Jim Jordan, and other right-wingers come from this generational group.  Their original hero and father-figure was Reagan.  They are quick to give Trump a pass because his values reflect theirs:  the supremacy of private property and the free market, business is where its at and that business-people are the object of society.  They double down on Evangelical religion, which reinforces capitalism.

They pride themselves on putting the country right, in contrast to what they see as dissolute baby-boomers.  But like Trump they leave nothing but devastation in their wake - their nihilistic spirit.  This demographic embodies decadence. 
 Trump will move on, but they have yet to reach their apogee.  More trouble ahead.
Trump's first term differs from Obama's first in one crucial aspect : Thanks to a blindly partisan Senate, Trump's appointment power has proceeded unchallenged and unimpeded.

This article brings to mind something Soren Kierkegaard, with his wonderful sense of irony, once wrote about "the present age” in the Europe of the nineteenth century in which he lived: Life had become so comfortable that it had become extremely difficult to lead an authentic existence. But this was good. Why? Because one can only lead an authentic existence if one's life is extremely difficult. And the comfort of the present age made this difficult. So, cheer up Ross. There's a purpose to decadence.

Mr. Douthat's column is at once provocative and provoking. Provocative, because he addresses macro-level tendencies that are often obscured by our all consuming focus on the now and the next thing. We are not particularly good at taking the longer view; Mr. Douthat's column is a reminder to do so.

Provoking, because he omits the greatest consequence of decadence, the looming global environmental crisis. This crisis exists in macro-level patterns of thought and action assuming inevitable progress, growth, and development. But it exists also in meso-level the political movements, particularly populist movements, whose effects Mr. Douthat takes too lightly. Calling the Trump moment reality television glosses over how it both legitimates and gratifies micro-level grievances, giving cover to political decisions whose immediately destructive environmental consequences are obscured by a befogged state of mind similar to Huxley's soma. 

Environmental decadence will have considerably greater consequences than any Mr. Douthat considers and presses more urgently for attention than do faulty business plans.

Our current age is bound to appear to be an age of decadence when compared with the age before it, which was an age of wonders.  The period that we compare it with, from say 1670 to 1970 included the European settlement of North America, the independence and growth of the United States, the rise of republican government, the creation and end of European colonial empires, the inventions of the the railroad, steam ship, automobile, airplane, telegraph, telephone, radio, television, and electronic computer, among many other things.

A tiny example: After Lincoln was elected to the Congress in 1846, he traveled to Washington to take up his position.  He didn't hurry, but he didn't dawdle much either.  It took him about six weeks.  On election day 1860 candidate Lincoln went down to the Springfield telegraph office to watch the returns come in, and he knew by midnight that he had been elected President, which is about as fast as we can know such things now.  This was future shock.

It’s no surprise that our modern age by contrast appears decadent.

This is an especially interesting article. I would just add another point. There is a hopelessness in a world in which the traditional population pyramid is upside down and there are increasing numbers of the elderly and smaller and smaller cohorts of the very young. This certainly must come in part from people focusing more on their own individual pleasure than on any  familial or communal  good. The Age of Narcissism thesis.
Hopelessness also may come from humanity's awareness of its understanding that it will never have the capability to travel to the furthest regions of the galaxy much less the universe. The fact that we see ourselves as the center only of ourselves may mean a loss in our motivation to explore and discover more of the Universe.

The financialization of the US economic system has drawn resources into short term schemes to create profits, e.g. Private equity's explosion, the proliferation of MBAs.  I believe the % of corporate spending on R&D has slowed significantly.  Banking and finance used to be a smaller % of our economy and boring and stable.  Now it's like Vegas...

This was worth reading and brings up many things worth thinking about and/or continuing to think about and/or act on.  There's the look of the 'very ambitious' to this, a vague resemblance to some of Joan Didion's old pieces in the New York Review of Books, but although worthwhile, is not nearly so sharp throughout.  But I write this comment because I think there are couple of inaccuracies that ought to be pointed out.

1)  The farther you get from that iPhone glow, the clearer it becomes: Our civilization has entered into decadence.

That actually goes against most of what Douthat has written about the internet and the healthiness of getting away from it.  The farther away from the IPhone, you won't see more decadence than you did on that iPhone or your own degenerate addiction to it.  By now, I am often in clubs where I'm the only person without an iPhone, and having even lied about 'my iPhone', which I have never owned.  But you also see how to create from what's outside the iPhone, and that now even can include some specifically sexual creation.  This may have been, however, intended somewhat otherwise, but on the face of it, it does contradict much of what Douthat has said regarding internet addiction.  

2) This seems more serious, but I have to make it as a separate comment or a reply to my own comment (this one), because the body got too long.

Decadence and the human race?

You could probably argue the human race has always been decadent, that there has always been something wrong with it, because it's never really happy, satisfied, is always getting sick, dying, struggling against nature, never staying in one place, indeed dreaming of getting off the planet.

Much is made these days of humans ruining the environment, being an ecological disaster, bringing millions of species to extinction, causing climate change, but you could easily argue that probably less than 10% of people actually like nature, are willing to tolerate bugs, temperature changes, wild animals, all the stuff of actually being outdoors; for the most part people actually hate nature, are always removing pests (rats, mice, insects, etc.), are always developing cities; indeed cities are the answer and nature is mostly a problem. 

Humans are always vaccinating themselves, fixing themselves, erecting walls, protections, barriers to point that there is perhaps no species more sensitive, with as soft and in need of protection underbelly than the human species. The typical futuristic dream is of a sterile, nonnatural world where humans are stronger, smarter, with incredible powers, and one of the deepest fears and insults is that we might be insects or the like, a pest to be crushed underfoot.

It's hard to consider ourselves healthy when we have so much evidence of ourselves being contemptible, sick,--indeed our heroism is a perpetual search for health.

Great article! Mr. Douhat's concern that we've erected a digital Crystal Palace is well founded. I believe we and our ecosystem will need us to implement some Luddite-like restraints, similar to our self-imposed constraints on genetic manipulation in human beings (and other living organisms). The author's link to William Wilson's "Replication Crisis" was the best citation in a NYT op-ed article I've seen in years (and great to see after enduring the profound corruption of the Democratic party in Iowa AND this very newspaper.) The commodification of scientific research and the glossing over of negative results is greatly responsible for misguiding our paths in science and technology and many cultural movements based on these, IMO.

With regard to long-term robustness/sustainability (but probably not religion), modern American society could learn a lot from our Amish, Mennonite and other technology-cautious communities. The socioeconomic system of our capitalist country promotes large-scale agriculture and industry. It INHERENTLY increases the economic scale and level of production, which clearly is a bad thing for our ecosystem and our long-term (and often short-term) welfare.

IMO, we may need to limit capitalism to help change our socioeconomic system to one that does not inherently ramp up the scale and level of commercial activity. A system favoring small-scales would promote long-term commercial activity, quality over quantity outputs and sustainable values added.

Where does it fit in that we spend $700B plus on the military industrial complex?  What does that get us?  
 Or that, essentially, we have not figured out that every advancement to humanity exacts a cost on humanity - eg, costly healthcare innovations that extend life extracting resources that would go to other aspects of life.  
We need to have some really difficult and complex and adult conversations about our values, priorities and objectives. Not sure the two party systems sets us up for success.

Wow. this is the most incisive piece of writing I've read in a long time. Some loose associations:1) We are reminded that the end of the roman empire was punctuated by demagogues and opportunist that falsely took on the mantle of populists 2) The parallel  with the religious experience; the first generation had the experience, the second generation build the temples , the third generation found them empty and the fourth generation destroyed them and started allover.3) The American experience was built on challenges, surviving, discovering, expanding, leading. We are in need of new challenges but inner and outer.

Our species was stable and stagnant for 100,000 years before urbanization began. But we evolved tremendously during that time.

Maybe it's time again for economic stagnation and inner growth. That might save us from environmental collapse.

Mr Douthat confounds  cultural and political decadence with its consequences. Better to claim that decadence in people and societies is a degeneration, a betrayal  of the higher personal and public virtues. It is moral turpitude in which the passion of  personal self- absorption , and indulgence in the pleasures of self-interest valorizes self loyalty as the highest ethical value.
It is pathological narcissism welded to a  cynical certainty  that the golden age, what ever it once was, is gone.  It defines a world without virtues unconstrained by ethical rules and entirely devoted to self interest. From such a  decay, all the vices of modern 21st century politics become merely anecdotes..

Douthat says "we are aging, comfortable and stuck, cut off from the past."  Well, no. Lots of us are young and very uncomfortable. We are not cut off from the past so much as cut off from our future. We are not exhausted "at a high level of material prosperity" because we never attained that.

He says the US is "extraordinarily wealthy", and that "its middle class prosperous beyond the dreams of centuries past." But the US is drowning in debt, which republicans ignore, just as they deny climate crisis, when both loom as imminent catastrophes.

Decadence, as in a state of decay, is exactly what the US is, when we accept that ignorance is best, truth is nothing, facts inadmissible, and might makes right. When sub-mediocrity is the norm, banality, cruelty and vulgarity are the standards by which we measure ourselves, when the leader is a thug and a gross caricature of a bloated plutocrat, then we steeping in decadence.

Amen Ross...what a powerful and important piece after a week of dystopian politics. So appreciate your perspective always and this is very wise.

I would add that there is an undercurrent of fear in many of us based on the science surrounding climate change so the need for awakened renewal is very real in real time. 

And  I would add to your overall thesis that if we can trust in the evolutionary pull forward  that renewal can bring about a sense of spiritual humility that sees all humanity as interconnected and supports us in engaging our renewal efforts with a sense of love, looking at the world through fresh eyes. 

Deep Blessings and much gratitude always.

How you can describe MAGA as anti stagnation confounds me. I just read in this paper how trump wants a LAW that all federal buildings to be in the classical style. No innovation, no imagination. This administration is decadent in all meaning.

RD must know that there is a technological solution to global warming and all other potential environmental disasters, one that can be implemented with no innovation  and without upsetting the rich and powerful.  Otherwise he could not think that our situation is sufficiently stable to be called "decadence".

I've found some of Mr. Douthat's columns questionably thin in their broadness of view, but this is an impressive piece of work.

Initially put off by a re-defining of 'decadence' from its most popular one, of sensual excess, his subsequent sections well clarified his (and J Barzun's) thinking. 

Seeming progress can actually be stagnation when it devolves into endless variations on an original breakthrough. YAA! - Yet Another App. Combined with hype-even-unto-deceit, human catastrophes abound while real problems of poverty and pollution not only go unaddressed, they willfully are being made worse. 

There was a bumper sticker in the 80's, "Kill Your Television," seen on some musical instrument cases. I'm sure we'd be better off as a nation now if that notion had actually taken a popular hold. Beware the electronic  hypnotism of constant motion that catches the eye and with it the brain. 

In lieu of that - vote, and convince others to vote. We have the votes, but we also are having a crisis of confidence we cannot afford to have. Let's get out there.

Jeez, why the dig at chocolate covered strawberries? They're a simple pleasure, and simple pleasures are to be appreciated (although I prefer strawberries sans chocolate).  Better to ask--where to obtain the sweet strawberries of yore, rather than the disturbingly crunchy, probably dyed, big-agriculture grocery store strawberries. We need to connect with our physical world, and taking care of it is the central challenge of our time, something we can and should unify around. Ross probably would say that religion is the answer to our malaise; but I'd argue that we need a spiritual focus that is non-theocratic. Children in school should have more art, music, gardening, field trips to forests, hands-on science that will help them solve the problems of the future, and access to stories of history and civics that will help them feel the sweep of time.

I wish Ross had included an opinion about the effect of extreme wealth inequity in this well written essay. It takes time but historically it’s the major catalyst in societal breakdowns.

The revolutionary mob will arrive at the gated community hungry, angry and looking for their cake.

I’m old. The calendar aside, how do I know this? The only Grammy performers I have heard of are receiving lifetime achievement awards. Many of the history themed movies are about my friends and me.  I now know, kinds, how my parents felt when man learned to fly. I also know, unfortunately, what my dad meant when he said, “wait til your friends start dying”. I still get tears in my eyes when a space launch occurs. Computers? “Is Ian (my grandson) there. Yeah, send him over, I think I just bought 300 pairs of shoes on Amazon”. My daughter helped me find my place in all this when she said, “dad, you’re no longer a participant, now you’re a spectator”. Makes about as much sense as anything else. Brian nailed it...I just wasn’t made for these times.

The need for meaning and being part of a larger whole than our selves is deeply ingrained. This is especially true when we are young and not obligated to family and career. The next crisis is climate change. What we do about it will either end in a dystopian world where people and countries fight over diminishing resources and a smaller livable space or a world wide effort to innovate to change the way we live in a zero carbon emission world. The human drama is one of lurching from crisis to crisis. The last thirty years have been a nice siesta that will soon end.

Pick an old science fiction movie from more than ten years ago. Inevitably, you will see a future with flying cars, holographic billboards or other inventions we still don't have.  Also,we often see a date to set the film in time.

Movie makers have consistently overshot the progress we have made since their films debuted.

Is this decadence, or something else that looks like it?

The economy undergirds our civilization and hopes for a nice quiet decadence rest on the economy bearing the load - and that's the problem.

Economies require innovation: constant creative destruction and renewal. Without that, a handful of firms eventually rule everything and they further squelch innovation and use growing productivity to reduce wages and slowly impoverish everyone outside of their charmed circle.

We seem to have had a colossal burst of innovation this century, but in fact, the innovation took place last century and what we have is the exploitation of that innovation and the capturing of it by a handful of firms. Outside of that, Mr Douthat is right - innovation has declined.

The emergence of the trillion-dollar corporation is a sign of that stagnation. In a healthily innovative economy, the giants would have been repeatedly challenged by upstarts and could never have grown to their present immense size. They will all eventually stagnate, they may be doing so already, and as they do so our economy will suffer and so will our civilization.

At the end of Douthat's piece, he writes:
"that decadence need not give way to collapse to be escaped, that the renaissance can happen without the misery of an intervening dark age"

He is right to be cautiously optimistic. He is wrong in that the "collapse" is already upon us, and the "dark age" is beginning, but this time it's not about failed nations and world wars. Our planet is in trouble, and it's only going to get worse. That's why, if we're looking for a way out of decadence, we should focus our energy toward reinventing civilization in ways that are sustainable and encourage environmental stewardship. 

This turn is not pessimistic; it comes with countless opportunities for innovation, education, justice, and reconnection with the material world. And we need everyone for the effort, from silicon valley to the government, from farmers to industrialists. We need knowledge production from indigenous peoples, from PhDs and laboratories, and from artists unbound from societal constraints. Call it total war, call it a revolution, or call it a renaissance--this is *the* project for us to survive and thrive.

An excellent and well thought out piece, Mr. Douthat, and I rarely agree with your opinion pieces. We are fat, lazy, uninterested in anyone other than ourselves and what we can get right now, and have lost the generational wisdom of my grandparent's generation - those who suffered through the Great Depression, then WW2, only to rebound from a decade and a half of deprivation, desperation, pulling together for the common good of all, and creating the most prosperous civilization to date. The unfortunate side effect of their sacrifices was the Baby Boomers. Spoiled, self-entitled, the Me Generation who fought against "The Man" then partied in self-indulgence during the 1970s. Once they faced the reality of adulthood, they turned conservative and did everything they fought against in the 1960s - they became The Man. Then doubled and now tripled down on it. 

Now, here we are, all suffering the toxic side effects of the Me Generation. Does that absolve me, a Gen Xer, or my generation from not fighting against it? Certainly not. Here I am, a keyboard warrior, raging against my parent's generation but not doing nearly enough to really get out there to protest, rally, and fight against this decadence. We truly live in interesting times, as the old Chinese proverb says. I only hope that climate change will not get us all in the end despite the political, ideological, and religious divides.

In the 90's as the net was coming along, it typically felt like tomorrow would be a better days.  Go back to the space program days and expectations for the 21st century were stunningly optimistic.  

Now, particularly due to climate change, expectations are for slowly unfolding disaster, and inaction in the face of disaster.  There's no positive vision for a better tomorrow.  That bugs me.  I'm sure it bothers young people.  The best we can think of is no war and some solution to climate change.  That's ok but no where near inspiring enough for young people.

Thank you Mr. Douthat for a lot to digest. I didn't see "decadence as safe harbor" coming. Yes it's best and worst of times to quote a lesser Dickens novel.

The low-hanging fruit of science, tech, and medicine were picked in the first half of the 20th century. The world has been capitalizing ever since while the optimism of unlimited growth has waned. We admire strivers then become fixated on purveyors of vapor ware. (I'm a Prime Member to mention one you left out.) As you point out, gains increasingly accrue to the rentier class. So much of advanced economy is now founded on intellectual property but did we really have to grant protected status, e.g., to software that a 12-year-old could (and probably did) write releasing an army of one-click patent trolls?

The reason we are stuck is because our imagination, our verbiage and worst of all, our political class, is still rooted in the capitalism v. socialism model of the industrial age, benefiting institutional monopolists, both public and private. 

The decadence occurs when financial capital expands faster than real resources, creating speculative surpluses. There are plenty of new ideas and plenty opportunities to build on existing real capital, but it entails taking on the supra-national titans holding the excess financial capital. We can create a better world for our people to live in as long as we have a genuine democracy. Unfortunately vested interests  stand in the way. Instead of clearing the swamp, this administration, like its predecessors, is continuing to build on the misdirections of the Reagan/Thatcher era of economic libertarianism, and turning it into a gated community.

An enjoyable column to read.  My opinion is much "economic stagnation, institutional decay ... and intellectual exhaustion" is due to worsening income inequality.

A tiny number of massively wealthy persons and corporations use the Citizens United ruling to control the GOP who are now hard at work "deconstructing the administrative state" which is causing the institutional decay mentioned in the article. Regulations to keep our air and water safe cost money and corporations hate to incur these costs, so our safeguards are under attack. No wonder there is malaise.

To make ends meet, people peddle harder and work longer hours in an exhaustive race to maintain their status quo. They strive to pay mortgages on homes whose prices are driven to bubblicious heights by wealthy investors with tax cut money to throw at the stock and housing markets in a search for financial returns.

Back in the 1950s when tax rates were well higher there was money spent on infrastructure and research that laid the basis for the wealth that came our way in the 1960s-1990s. As tax rates have declined so has our stature in the world, and without this seed money there will be less bounty to harvest in our future.

Douthat is looking for anything to write about other than the fact that this week the  GOP proudly proclaimed that Trump is above the law and can openly conspire with America's enemies to rig the election.

Everything in this article amounts to a big fat "so what" when compared to the GOP's gleeful embrace of fascism.

To quote Oscar Wilde:

America is the only country that went from barbarism to decadence without civilization in between.

There are many interesting issues here but I will comment on 
the situation in science.  Commenters have contended that there are fantastic discoveries and there have been some, particularly in astronomy and molecular biology. However in
physics, I perceive some stagnation: Sean Carroll commented recently in a NYTimes piece that few in the community are seriously committed to inquiry into the poorly understood foundations of quantum mechanics. Quantum field theory continues after almost 75 years to depend on a mathematical kluge called renormalization which allows one
 to ignore the fact that it predicts empirically finite quantities to be infinite.  The prediction of a multitude of 'supersymmetric' particles at the Large Hadron Collider in its most recent run (endorsed by essentially the entire theoretical community) was not confirmed.  Though they have come up empty for decades, searches for 'dark matter' particles continue though other explanations for the astronomical phenomena which inspired the idea exist. 
Of course the failure of many theoretical predictions is not unexpected and is part of the process. What is remarkable is the near unanimity of the community about these predictions.
There seems to be a kind of intellectually sheeplike mentality at work.  But the sociological, educational, political or economic reasons for that are not completely clear to me
and space limitations do not permit elaboration of my speculations about them.

Beneath the shrewdly described emergent decadence, deeper forces drive. Over decades, slowly but with acceleration, humankind has been overshooting basic natural limits: of water supplies, reservoirs of genetic and species diversity, safe habitable climates, etc. Birth rates have dropped, but for decades have been unsustainably high, and our myopic economic systems still radically underprice our global natural capital, and squander much of it. 

The key choices ahead are thus not between growth and stagnation but between vibrant stability and unhinged decline. Furthermore, whether collective human spirit can lean more towards healthy renewal than towards unhealthy decadence, while important, probably matters less than whether we can achieve a soft landing to living within limits, rather than crashing into serial collapses. And rein in an out of control technology sector, steering it towards serving real human needs, instead of letting it manipulate and dehumanize us to fit its amoral business models and profit imperatives.
